story:
Summary

With trials ranging from political rebellion and corruption, sanitary inadequacies, disease catastrophe, war, and innocent bloodshed, Africa is under some of the worst conditions in the world. In such an underdeveloped country many misfortunes are unfixable, but many are also avoidable. Although there is no amount of money great enough to rebuild Africa, if we could simply educate on things as simple as washing hands, cooking food thoroughly, and unprotected sex, many lives would be spared throughout generations. My name is Paula Tapp, and I graduated from the University of Utah this past week in Psychology.  For as long as I can remember, I have always wanted to go to Africa. Throughout the years my understanding for the sincere need for health intervention and lack of medical health care needed thereof has solidified. My passion to help and need to intervene has only deepened. I have completed my first milestone in school with a Bachelors Degree in Psychology, and will continue my education in Social Work and Public Policy to use my degree to help others internationally. I completed a local internship through the Global Health Initiative at the University of Utah this spring, and have now been given the opportunity to be their representative this summer in Ghana, Africa. I will be teaching about public health, health prevention and promotion throughout various villages in Accra, Ghana. I will also be helping throughout hospitals and villages conducting health screenings, and participating in the international medical seminar in Kumasi, Ghana. My main focus while educating throughout the villages in Africa will be about unprotected sex, sanitation, and implications of individual and collective lifestyles. I want to implement public health interventions to reduce the levels of obesity, alcoholism, and inactivity in the country. I also will present findings from last years research collected on the community about elderly health, child mortality, and the importance of prenatal vitamins in childbearing women. Another responsibility while I am there will be conducting a survey on University of Utah students about their pre and post health related to their travels in Ghana to improve any health precautions suggested by the Global Health Initiative. 

What I Need

I am seeking a donation goal of $3,000. As you can imagine, a plane ticket alone to Africa is half the program cost. With the oil outrages going on in Africa right now, plane ticket prices are among the highest my advisors have seen at the Global Health Initiative. To save as much money as possible, I booked my plane ticket early at the beginning of April for my trip beginning June 26th. My plane ticket alone was almost $2,300 dollars. This doesn’t include my program costs to live in Africa for one month with University Physician Assistants for the first 10 days, and implementing Public Health for the last 20 days. Program costs include food, shelter, bus fares, travel expenses/luggage fees, yellow fever, meningococcal, typhoid, malaria, and polio vaccinations and medications, Ghana visa application fee to stay and enter into the country, bug repellents/nets needed, and evacuation insurance required. My total cost is going to be an estimated price of $6,000. The expenses above do not mention costs to maintain bills at home while away, and not receiving income for that month. If I can reach my goal, I will be able to pay for my program and internship opportunity without loans. If our research, teachings, and health surveys are successful, I may have the opportunity to publish the findings and go to Washington D.C next spring for the Global Health Initiative. It would be great to be able to beat my goal so that I can actually receive the full $3,000 to go towards my program after website fees. This website takes a 3% of my goal if my number is reached, and 9% if it is not reached, so please any amount is greatly appreciated!

The Impact

 In Ghana, an estimated amount of 18,000 people die from AIDS per year, 350-500 million from parasites (the leading cause of death), and now non-communicable diseases including diabetes, hypertension, stroke and cancers, have slipped into the top 10 causes of morbidity and mortality in Ghana. While I am there I have specific topics that I will be assigned to educate about, and the rest of the topics I get to choose based on the need in particular areas. These statistics above are why I am choosing to focus teaching about sanitation, unprotected sex, and nutritional and lifestyle impacts on physical health. I am excited to educate in Africa not only to benefit my personal growth and long-term goals in my career of humanitarian work, but also as an experience that will help give me more insight, understanding, and compassion for others around the world. With a sincere desire to help others, I hope to serve and teach the Ghanaian people in order to benefit and help them as much as I know they will benefit me. I am setting out to make a difference, and I need your help. To those of you who cannot contribute, that doesn’t mean that you can’t help. Spread the word to any and everyone about the campaign. This is going to be an opportunity of a lifetime that I hope can impact generations to come to the developing country and local people in Ghana, Africa.

story:
My name is Suzette and I am 63 years old.  I am in the final stages of COPD.  I had to leave my Job March 2011 due to this illness.  Losing my job was not just losing my salary but  also losing my insurance.  I am on disability with the government.  I receive a check that covers my rent and electric bill, but nothing else.   I cannot receive any insurance through this program until September 2013.  There is a 2 year waiting period to receive Medicaid and Medicare.  I have not had any of my medication in 11 months.  With what I have to take daily, on a monthly basis without insurance it cost $l600.00 a month. I also am so oxygen 24/7 and now without my insurance they want me to pay $542.00 monthly.  Taking the medication will not cure my disease, but it would make quality of life a little easier.  I have worked all of my life and done what I had to do to get by.  Asking anyone for anything is so hard for me.  But I do not know where else to turn except to strangers.

The last time I was in the hospital, which was 3 months ago, the doctor said I probable had about 6 months.  I want to prove him wrong, for only one reason that is important to me.  I have never been the type of person that needed alot.  I felt blessed with what I had.  But now there is only one thing that I want to do.  I want to live to see my oldest grandson graduate from high school.  That happens May 2013, It would mean the world to me and him.  I might be able to make it if I could get started back on medication.  I have never been one to give up on things, and this is no exception.  If there is anything I can do to stay that long, I will do.  But I can't do it without a little help.  And this help is only for medication to help me fight, just a little while longer.

What ever you could give no matter how small, would be appreciated.  If you are not in the position to give, that is ok, but could you please spread the word.  Thank you so much, and God Bless You.

story:
Spinal Cord Injury and Sri Lanka

Spinal cord injury has a devastating effect on a person's life and their family. 

Sri Lanka has a population of around 20 million people. It is estimated that roughly 1,800 spinal cord injuries take place in the country annually. In 2011, it was estimated that around 6 people a day may die from spinal cord injury without treatment. While life-expectancy for people who have suffered a spinal cord injury is around two years without rehabilitation, it is normal with rehabilitation. 

The spinal unit based in Colombo is the only acute care rehab facility in primary trauma centre.

 

What do we do and where are we at?

Our job is to provide acute care at the beginning of an injury to prevent complications of paralysis.

The 18 month old unit is run by a group of extremely passionate doctors, nurses, therapists and support staff. They do an amazing job with what little resources they have.

What do we mean by low resources? Until recently, the physiotherapist was managing with 2kg sandbags as weights for exercising patients. The unit had very few catheters for intermittent catheterisation available. The staff have been waiting for a pat-slide to transfer patients from bed-to-bed for more than a year.

These are all things we take for granted back home in places like Australia and U.S. 

 

What else is needed?

Apart from the unit itself, the organisation is currently building a half-way home to help patients transition from the unit to home and the community. This will hopefully serve as a model and provide skills for patients to survive when they return home.

A majority of the patients are from low income backgrounds and face enormous personal challenges due to a comparative lack of long term support. There is a needd for access to transport, long-term care or support services.

There is a huge focus on spinal cord research and cure at the moment which is fantastic. We desperately need a cure. At the same time, it'll be great if we can support spinal cord injury patients and units like this who need help to get by. 

With your help, this passionate unit can start to tackle the mammoth task of implementing a great care system for spinal cord injury patients.

 

Spinal Injury Costs for a Patient

Just to give you an idea, in the U.S, the average annual medical cost for a spinal injury patient according to the CDC is $15,000 to $30,000 per year. The estimated lifetime cost is $500,000 to more than $3 million depending on the severity of the injury. 

Granted, Sri Lanka's living costs are comparatively lower, but the average monthly household income is roughly USD$285. A lot of patients in the spinal unit come from low income backgrounds so their income can be less than a third of this figure.

While the country is developing quickly, spinal cord injury is not yet an area of focus so this issue as a whole as well as patients individually need a lot of help.

 

What We Need & What You Get

The unit currently needs the following equipment:

  • Pat-slide 
  • Nelaton catheters (12G/14G)
  • Cervical collars (soft, hard and philadelphia)
  • Thoraco-lumbar corsets
  • Plastic bowls and basins
  • Air mattresses
  • Physiotherapy equipment

The organisation as a whole is currently doing the following things:

  • Building a transition / half-way home  
  • Developing awareness and education campaigns for spinal cord injury patients
  • Developing long-term care and follow-up programs
  • Developing pre-hospital care programs
  • Developing education and training programs for other hospitals

Due to the devastating nature of the injury, patient morale can be quite low. So we hope to get some books for the patients depending on funding. The unit also requires some office consumables such as paper.

The unit is currently short around Rs. 3 or 4 million (roughly $25,000 - $30,000). The $5,000 goal will be a great start. Depending on how much funding we get, we can addresss each of these requirements in order of urgency and importance.

Spinal cord injury patients have a multitude of short and long term medical and social requirements. All this is still in its infancy so as you can imagine, this is a huge task.

Due to the shortage in funds, there aren't many perks we can offer. If you have any ideas, please let us know.

 

The Impact

The impact of your contribution is tremendous. For example, $2-3 is enough to buy a catheter. We hope that soon, with your help, spinal cord injury patients from this unit will be able to return home to pick up their life again to the best of their ability.

Your contribution will empower the staff and the patients to achieve this goal.

 

Why do I care?

I suffered a spinal cord injury (cervical - C6/C7) myself. I feel fortunate to have had access to the rehabilitation, services and support I received. I feel like I have a responsibility to help people who have access to less. That's why I'm trying to help.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Awareness is a big thing. If you can spread the word, that helps a lot. In fact, awareness and education about spinal cord injury in Sri Lanka is one of the major goals of the organisation.

We're open to any other ideas as well!

Air mattresses
Physiotherapy equipment

The organisation as a whole is currently doing the following things:

Building a transition / half-way home  
Developing awareness and education campaigns for spinal cord injury patients
Developing long-term care and follow-up programs
Developing pre-hospital care programs
Developing education and training programs for other hospitals

Due to the devastating nature of the injury, patient morale can be quite low. So we hope to get some books for the patients depending on funding. The unit also requires some office consumables such as paper.
The unit is currently short around Rs. 3 or 4 million (roughly $25,000 - $30,000). The $5,000 goal will be a great start. Depending on how much funding we get, we can addresss each of these requirements in order of urgency and importance.
Spinal cord injury patients have a multitude of short and long term medical and social requirements. All this is still in its infancy so as you can imagine, this is a huge task.
Due to the shortage in funds, there aren't many perks we can offer. If you have any ideas, please let us know.
 


The Impact
The impact of your contribution is tremendous. For example, $2-3 is enough to buy a catheter. We hope that soon, with your help, spinal cord injury patients from this unit will be able to return home to pick up their life again to the best of their ability.
Your contribution will empower the staff and the patients to achieve this goal.
 


Why do I care?
I suffered a spinal cord injury (cervical - C6/C7) myself. I feel fortunate to have had access to the rehabilitation, services and support I received. I feel like I have a responsibility to help people who have access to less. That's why I'm trying to help.
 
Other Ways You Can Help
Awareness is a big thing. If you can spread the word, that helps a lot. In fact, awareness and education about spinal cord injury in Sri Lanka is one of the major goals of the organisation.
We're open to any other ideas as well!

story:
(Above: Kevin on the day of his discharge from UCLA Medical Center, March 28th 2013.)

After what should have been a routine business trip to LA, our friend and colleague Kevin is back in Vancouver. His trip turned out to be a life-changing near-death experience at the UCLA Medical Center.  

Upon landing in LA, Kevin suffered a sudden cardiac arrest and collapsed. Thankfully, his friend Sonja Bennett reacted quickly and performed CPR on Kevin until an ambulance arrived.  After almost ten minutes of CPR and multiple rounds of elctrical shocks, the paramedics were able to get his pulse back and he was rushed to UCLA Medical Centre.  Once there, doctors put him in a coma and surgically implanted an ICD in his chest - a small device similar to a pace-maker that will detect if Kevin's heart ever stops again and correct it by delivering a jolt of electricity.

Kevin is now home and has made a full recovery.  He's already back at work with the consent of his doctors.  (It helps that his current workplace is the emergency department at Vancouver General Hospital!)

As Canadians, we would hope that travel insurance would save us in situations like this, but there can be complications to international situations and limitations to coverage.  Consequently, Kevin and his family incurred substantial out-of-pocket costs during this difficult time.

Ten days in an American hospital can obviously be quite expensive. We, his friends and colleagues, want to help him settle these unexpected bills, and show him we're glad he's still here.

Any funds that we can raise for him would have a huge impact. Not only would the contributions help with the medical costs, but they would also let him know that we all look out for one another in times of need.

Even if you are not able to contribute a monetary donation, there are other ways to help. Share this campaign with others, or simply send your well wishes to Kevin. 

To read more about Kevin's Medical Miracle check out this Province article: http://www.theprovince.com/mobile/entertainment...

story:
Hello everyone.

My name is Liezel Robles. I am 47 years old, a single mother, and I have been fighting cancer and other related conditions for the past 10 years. I survived breast cancer but, after 5 years in remission, a second cancer appeared in my gallbladder. That was 3 years ago, and it has since spread. My prognosis isn’t good (I’m now stage 4), but as part of my will to survive, I created a project called Oak Stories, where cancer patients can share, support, comfort and experiences. 

As part my involvement in Oak Stories, I have been recruited by others fighting cancer like myself to run the Disney World 2015 Marathon. As a marathon participant, I hope to be a source of courage to others facing adversity and an inspiration to those facing the daily challenges cancer brings their way. I particularly hope to be a source of courage and inspiration to my 10 year old son, but to do so I NEED YOUR HELP. 

I have already registered to take part in the marathon but will need to pay my way to get there from my home in the Republic of Panama. The estimated cost for my son, mom, and I to travel from Panama to Orlando, FL and be able to participate is about $9,000, of which I have already raised $6000.00 locally thanks to the generosity of numerous people.  I hope you too can help.

Whether or not you can make a donation, thank you for reading my story. Despite the challenges I have endured and those yet to come, I am both humbled and thrilled by the number of people who have supported me throughout this journey.

Love,

Liezel

http://heroesporpanama.com/?page_id=6794

story:
THE PROBLEM: The challenge of medicine in war ravaged Syria

Imagine being THE person that a community of more than 10000 relies upon to provide healthcare in a war ravaged city with poor sanitation and dangerous conditions. Imagine providing care beyond your comfort zone and beyond your training without the most basic of resources to do so.  Imagine that every time you act to save another, your own life is in danger, simply for providing care. Imagine the horrors you have seen and those you continue to face every day.  

This is what life is like for doctors and medical students who remain in Syria. Subjected to prison, torture, attack and death, simply for providing care to  civilians in need, few doctors remain in the country to carry the burden.

"To be a doctor in Syria means you are always saving other peoples' lives - while your own life is in danger all the time. Since it is the government forces attacking civilians, the same government tries to prevent us from treating them. So every day they are trying to kill us, too."                            Dr. Majed Aboali, Duma, Syria.

https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/doctors-syria-years-living-dangerously-annie-sparrow?redirectFromSplash=true

YOU CAN HELP: $13 for safe paediatric medicine

You can provide a simple tool that will make a huge difference every day, for the cost of lunch and a coffee at your hospital cafe.  

As a paediatric doctor, I know the importance of being able to determine what dose of medication is appropriate for a given child in front if me. Too much and it could kill or seriously harm them. Too little and it will not be effective. Anyone who works with children will know the value of our drug dosing guides and many of you will use one up to hundreds of times a day. Today many of us can access an app to do so, however this is not the case in  Syria with electricity unreliable and phone use reserved for alerts about incoming threats and local bombings. Remember the pre-app days of carrying a pocket sized book that contained per kilo dosing of all the important medications you could need? They still exist and in Syria can and will save lives.  For those of you who don't work with children, imagine suddenly needing to do so (for nobody else can) and having no idea where to even start with medications.  Doctors remaining in Syria are asking for these drug books and you can help.  For just A$13 you can provide a paediatric drug doses handbook to a doctor working in Syria.

HOW WE WILL PROVIDE: Hand delivered to Syrian Doctors Nov 2015

Dr Annie Sparrow, an Australian intensive care paediatrician and  global health specialist now based at The Mount Sinai Global Health Center (http://www.gh-training.org/staff/#staff1965 ), has been working with those directly affected by the Syrian conflict since its early days.  In 2015 Dr Sparrow was nominated for the Australian of the Year Award for her work. In spite of little global attention to the conflict until very recently and limited resources she has continued to travel to the border of Turkey and Syria numerous times a year to train Syrian doctors in paediatric critical care, in order to equip them to better serve those suffering. Syrian doctors she works with frequently ask her for a drug doses book, just like the one she carries. Of all she has  come across throughout her work across the globe, the paediatric Drug Doses Manual by Frank Shann, produced by the Royal Children's Hospital , Melbourne is the best suited for such conditions. Small, lightweight and easy to keep on you at all times, ready for whatever you are faced with next.

Each book costs just $13.  Books will be hand delivered to Syrian doctors by Dr Annie Sparrow  (traveling from the US) at a training camp on the Turkey-Syria border in early November 2015. We aim to raise enough funds for 200 books (though more would be a bonus).  That is just 200 doctors giving 1 book each! 

We need YOUR help and we need it NOW. 

Time is short to raise funds given the upcoming training camp.  Please donate  now to truly make a difference to those in need. 

If excess funds are raised, we will simply purchase books to the value of raised funds and distribute these also.

Your help is immensely appreciated and will continue to serve those suffering in Syria. 

Thankyou.

Read more by Dr Annie Sparrow here:

Syria's Polio Epidemic: The Suppressed Truth by Annie ...

www.nybooks.com/articles/.../syrias-polio-epidemic-suppressed-truth/


Syria: The Other Threat by Annie Sparrow | NYR Daily | The ...

www.nybooks.com/blogs/nyrblog/2014/aug/12/syria-threat-polio/


Health Activist Annie Sparrow's Fight to End Polio - Vogue

www.vogue.com/.../health-activist-annie-sparrow-polio-outbreak-syria/

story:
We have now closed both of our campaigns.  

We are working on making the sensors even better than what we promised.   From 1st of March 2015 we are in GE Healthcare 'Health Innovative Village' in Helsinki.  Come and visit us and check out our R&D if you are in town.

Thank you for your support!   

To order V1bes, please send an email to: info(at)v1bes.com

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

THE V1BES CAMPAIGN CONTINUES:  We had such a great exhibition at CES in Las Vegas that we decided to extend the campaign.  This does not change any commitments or deals done in the previous V1bes campaign.  Neither have we changed perks or terms.   This way we want to make it possible to still order V1bes over Indiegogo.  

 v1bes extended campaign


Why V1bes?

The stress you feel throughout the day, and in your body and life, is caused by multiple factors. We - at the V1bes team have not settled for a measurement of your pulse from an arm band to be your stress detector.  The optically measured pulse is a limited stress indicator. Stress has many causes. To understand them better, we have created a triple bio-signal sensor - all in one ring. By measuring the electrical signals from brainwaves, heart rate and electromagnetic field-absorption, you receive a more complete understanding of what causes your stress. This is the foundation for knowing how to manage it. Know yourself, revive yourself.


How can I use it?  How does it help me?


V1bes STRESS METER



Know and control your stress levels.  V1bes looks at stress both in the body and from the environment.    To detect it we look at brainwaves, heart rate and molecular stress arising in your body from surrounding electromagnetic pollution.  When having done the tests (EEG, ECG and EMF), you will can see how your stress levels change in the stress meter.   

The V1bes Stress Meter shows your latest tests and compares them with earlier tests or reference data.   Our beta-testers has for instance noticed that the stress meter is very handy when evaluating how mediation or yoga is 'working'.   Different people react differently to various practices.     Make the first test before and the second test after.     You can also make regular tests in the mornings to compare with your reference data.   There are many ways how to use the results to improve and control your stress levels.       

The written conclusions can look like this:


1) Brainwave test (EEG)

 


2) Heart Rate Test (ECG)


Your heart tells a lot about you and your stress.  By combining brainwave stress indicators and heart rate variability, we know much more.  


3) Electromagnetic Pollution Test (EMF)


The electromagnetic fields are all around you and they can cause stress.   See the very low frequency fields with V1bes.   Measure your bed or check that your baby is sleeping in a low-pollution place.    Test your car (join our car-rating project)  or see how much EMF-pollution comes from your tablet screen.   

OUR FUN-APPS

1) Biceps competition 


We love the sledgehammer 'power-man' test at the local fairs so we built one for V1bes.   It measure's the electric activity in your muscles and the competition app tells 'who  is the strongest'.


2)  'Bio-Selfie'

Your heart's electrical frequency picture is also your exclusive 'neuro-electrical fingerprint'.  That's why we make a bio-selfie from it.   The colors and forms tell about you.   The bio-selfie seems to reveal personality traits.

Have a look and compare V1bes BioSelfies at www.b1oselfie.com


3) Match:  See how your vibes change from touch


We don't know it all yet, but we know that there definitely is something in the vibes. It influence's how we feel about others.   Measure how her touch change's your vibes.   And she doesn't even have to touch.   When she stands near you, her fields will change yours.  You can see it on V1bes.

INFO


What do I get when I order V1bes?

  1. Ring sensor
  2. Stand unit (acting as antenna and docking station)
  3. Controller
  4. Cables for connection and charging
  5. One year free storage of test data in My V1bes (Google cloud)


The V1bes App


The V1bes app shows in real time the voltage fluctuations and frequency analysis  of the most important frequency ranges.  You also choose test-program and start the tests from this simple display.   The App is open source and we hope that as many as possible join us to develop more applications.


My V1bes cloud storage

When making a test, it is automatically stored in your My V1bes folder.   There you can download and look at all your previous tests.  Compare your current heart-curve with older ones.   The My V1bes cloud will also have numerous facilities for sharing, forwarding and deeper analyzing.   We are proponents of the individuals rights to her or his data.  This data is yours and you are free to do whatever you want  with it.

What have we done so far?

We started this project in 2012.   We have done hundreds of prototypes and thousands of tests.   We competed in the Nokia Sensing XCHALLENGE.  We have participated in numerous seminars and conferences.   It has been a long path and we are happy to finally be ready for crowdfunding sales.
Here are some example of our past prototypes.   These have been presented at the 2013 and 2014 Quantified Self Conferences in San Francisco and Amsterdam.  



Timeline and how we use the funds

We need your support to spread (good) V1bes globally.   Your funds will be used for final design, production setup, finalizing the Android- & iOS apps and improving the feedback features.   All of these are almost ready but we want to make them even better. 

Our timeline:

  • Nov 14th - Indiegogo Launch
  • Nov 18-19th at SLUSH in Helsinki - come and visit us
  • January 6-9th at CES in Las Vegas - come and visit us
  • March-May 2015 - V1bes delivered to partner SDK clients (handmade)
  • August 2015 - our deadline for final design, apps and feedback features
  • September-November 2015 - V1bes serial production deliveries


Technical Details

V1bes comes loaded with the latest measurement and wireless technology. Here is a short pick from the details:

  • One silver coated dry electrode touching the finger for continuous body-measurement and a silver tube as antenna for environment measurements and acting as touch electrode for EEG, ECG and EMG.
  • It is measuring 256 times per second and this data is sent by a Zigbee wireless signal to the smartphone/tablet (via the Controller) where we analyze it's very low frequencies  in the range of 0,5-128 Hz.

For more information on technical details, please click: Technical Specifications


Questions and Answers

Q: How does it work?   

A:  V1bes detects the very subtle voltage fluctuations between the sensors skin electrode (under the ring, touching the finger) and the antenna electrode (silver tube).   The V1bes app and cloud then analyze these signal's frequencies.

Q Is it harmful?  

A:  The V1bes measurement is passive and does not induce electrical- or other impulses into the human body (as compared to bio-impedance or many optical sensors).  It uses a Zigbee radio signal as we consider it to be the least harmful available wireless protocol for the human body.

Q: Can V1bes be used on iOS and Android?

A: Yes.  We will have apps both for iPhone and Android devices.

Q:  When will you deliver the sensors?

A:  From serial production and IOS we deliver during 3Q 2015.  SDK sensors for Android are shipped within 2 months.  For CES 2015 clients which use Android, we also deliver withing 2 months. 

Q:  What if you don't reach your goal?  Will you still deliver?

A:  Yes we will definitely deliver even if we don't reach the goal.   We assemble the sensors in Finland as 3D printed versions.  We are fully committed to ship because the main idea of this campaign is to get initial users and experience.   We are in it for the long run - this is only the beginning.

Q: How are the ring sizes going to work?

A: Currently we use strap band which you tighten to a good fit on your finger.  The current version is not intended to be on the finger continuously.  The strap band makes it easy for several persons to use the same ring.   

Q: How long will battery last with a full charge?  And how do you charge it?

A: With our current prototype, depending on usage, battery can last up to 15 hours.  Charging takes about 90 minutes.   The battery can be changed.  The battery is charging from normal USB computer port or standard USB charger.

Q: Are you able to ship internationally?

A: Yes and shipping by standard mail is included.  

Q: Does the price include VAT (Value Added Tax)

A: No, we cannot take into account regional VAT in this campaign.  There may be a VAT surcharge payable by the buyer if the local authorities so demands.

Q: Is V1bes a formal medical device?

A: No, and currently we have no plans to file for FDA or similar approvals.  

Q:  How do I wear the V1bes ring?

A:  The sensor shal be on your right hand index finger with the silver antenna pointing to the left.   

Q:  What does the Stress-Test measure?

A:  The Stress Test Meter shows all three stress tests in one meter.   First you measure your brainwaves by leaning your hand against the forehead (25 secs, test #2), then you keep the hand in the air for a 25 seconds surround test and finally you do the heart-rate stress test for 25 seconds.  Now the Stress Meter will show all these three tests in one picture.   The meter also shows your previous tests which you have done with test button 1.   This way you can see your stress levels 'before' or compare to a reference measurements of your 'normal' de-stressed self.      

Team:

For full details about all of us, please click: Meet our team

When making a test, it is automatically stored in your My V1bes folder.   There you can download and look at all your previous tests.  Compare your current heart-curve with older ones.   The My V1bes cloud will also have numerous facilities for sharing, forwarding and deeper analyzing.   We are proponents of the individuals rights to her or his data.  This data is yours and you are free to do whatever you want  with it.

What have we done so far?
We started this project in 2012.   We have done hundreds of prototypes and thousands of tests.   We competed in the Nokia Sensing XCHALLENGE.  We have participated in numerous seminars and conferences.   It has been a long path and we are happy to finally be ready for crowdfunding sales.
Here are some example of our past prototypes.   These have been presented at the 2013 and 2014 Quantified Self Conferences in San Francisco and Amsterdam.  





Timeline and how we use the funds

We need your support to spread (good) V1bes globally.   Your funds will be used for final design, production setup, finalizing the Android- & iOS apps and improving the feedback features.   All of these are almost ready but we want to make them even better. 
Our timeline:



Nov 14th - Indiegogo Launch


Nov 18-19th at SLUSH in Helsinki - come and visit us


January 6-9th at CES in Las Vegas - come and visit us


March-May 2015 - V1bes delivered to partner SDK clients (handmade)


August 2015 - our deadline for final design, apps and feedback features


September-November 2015 - V1bes serial production deliveries



Technical Details
V1bes comes loaded with the latest measurement and wireless technology. Here is a short pick from the details:


One silver
     coated dry electrode touching the finger for continuous body-measurement
     and a silver tube as antenna for environment measurements and acting as touch electrode for EEG, ECG and EMG.


It is measuring 256 times per second and this data is sent by a Zigbee wireless signal to the smartphone/tablet (via the Controller) where we analyze it's very low frequencies  in the range of 0,5-128 Hz.


  

For more information on technical details, please click: Technical Specifications

Questions and Answers




Q: How does it work?   
A:  V1bes detects the very subtle voltage fluctuations between the sensors skin electrode (under the ring, touching the finger) and the antenna electrode (silver tube).   The V1bes app and cloud then analyze these signal's frequencies.
Q Is it harmful?  
A:  The V1bes measurement is passive and does not induce electrical- or other impulses into the human body (as compared to bio-impedance or many optical sensors).  It uses a Zigbee radio signal as we consider it to be the least harmful available wireless protocol for the human body.
Q: Can V1bes be used on iOS and Android?
A: Yes.  We will have apps both for iPhone and Android devices.

Q:  When will you deliver the sensors?
A:  From serial production and IOS we deliver during 3Q 2015.  SDK sensors for Android are shipped within 2 months.  For CES 2015 clients which use Android, we also deliver withing 2 months. 

Q:  What if you don't reach your goal?  Will you still deliver?
A:  Yes we will definitely deliver even if we don't reach the goal.   We assemble the sensors in Finland as 3D printed versions.  We are fully committed to ship because the main idea of this campaign is to get initial users and experience.   We are in it for the long run - this is only the beginning.

Q: How are the ring sizes going to work?
A: Currently we use strap band which you tighten to a good fit on your finger.  The current version is not intended to be on the finger continuously.  The strap band makes it easy for several persons to use the same ring.   
Q: How long will battery last with a full charge?  And how do you charge it?
A: With our current prototype, depending on usage, battery can last up to 15 hours.  Charging takes about 90 minutes.   The battery can be changed.  The battery is charging from normal USB computer port or standard USB charger.
Q: Are you able to ship internationally?
A: Yes and shipping by standard mail is included.  
Q: Does the price include VAT (Value Added Tax)
A: No, we cannot take into account regional VAT in this campaign.  There may be a VAT surcharge payable by the buyer if the local authorities so demands.
Q: Is V1bes a formal medical device?
A: No, and currently we have no plans to file for FDA or similar approvals.  
Q:  How do I wear the V1bes ring?
A:  The sensor shal be on your right hand index finger with the silver antenna pointing to the left.   

Q:  What does the Stress-Test measure?
A:  The Stress Test Meter shows all three stress tests in one meter.   First you measure your brainwaves by leaning your hand against the forehead (25 secs, test #2), then you keep the hand in the air for a 25 seconds surround test and finally you do the heart-rate stress test for 25 seconds.  Now the Stress Meter will show all these three tests in one picture.   The meter also shows your previous tests which you have done with test button 1.   This way you can see your stress levels 'before' or compare to a reference measurements of your 'normal' de-stressed self.      
Team:



For full details about all of us, please click: Meet our team

story:
Refuge Trauma & Counseling Center Building Funds

Our program is designed for Military Veterans and Civilians.

Every man who enters our program has encountered the life-shattering consequences of trauma; whether they have sacrificed by choice or by survival.  60.7% of men have experienced a traumatic event in their lives. Although not a complete list, the most common events are sexual assault, combat, and childhood abuse.  The graphic video (Blue Three Productions, 2010) above is a devastating example of what PTSD looks like on a day to day basis; although this is a Veteran's story, the symptoms are not unique to veterans - which is why we seek to provide a place of Refuge for all suffering from trauma.

Without treatment and support, PTSD causes devastating effects in the lives of these veterans and civilians and for their families... in fact:

  • 27% of those diagnosed with PTSD attempt suicide; 22 Veterans a day are successful.
  • Divorce rate among civilians is 54%; for returned Veterans it's 84%.

Our Calling:

Refuge Trauma & Counseling Center - is a unique concept in the care and treatment of men afflicted with PTSD and for their families. Our goal is to bring each man to resiliency and reunification:

  • Through Counseling
  • Through Experience
  • Through Family

Our Mission:

This calling is to be fulfilled by building a safe and secure environment for our clients to heal from trauma and to re-learn their accountability as husbands, fathers, family members and friends. Clients' individual goals for reunification will be achieved by tapping into their natural potential for resiliency.

Building barracks-style housing will aid clients with comfortably familiar surroundings while they transition into and out of intensive short-stay or alternative long-term inpatient treatment. During their stay, these men will work as a unit to support each other through their healing and to build important relationship skills.

Additionally, creating the onsite counseling center will provide access to care for the community and families of our clients.

Our Experience:

Our founders represent the skills and experiences that will make this program a success.  Adam is a United States Military Veteran who has experienced combat trauma, has career experience in Information Systems, and strong leadership skills. Our founding partner, Shannon, is a Licensed Counselor completing her PhD in Trauma & Crisis. For nine years, she has directed a  counseling center which specializes in trauma and resiliency;  she has also created trauma programs applicable to other organizations.

Our Provision:

Three levels of care are established to offer a safe and secure environment for men and the program's focus will emphasize reunification by including family therapy.

  • Level One - to provide traditional outpatient  services to the community, regardless of race or gender and to include individual, couples and family counseling  -with established goals of resiliency and reunification
  • Level Two - to provide alternative intensive seven-day inpatient treatment with focus on resiliency while working within the confines of external needs such as job requirements or family obligations
  • Level Three - to provide alternative long-term (9-month) inpatient treatment with the same goals as levels one and two. Three phases of this program level include stabilization, trauma treatment, and reunification.  This program's focus will emphasize reunification by including family therapy. 

Modalities (treatment methods) like cognitive behavioral therapy and EMDR (eye movement desensitization and reprocessing) facilitate the accessing and processing of traumatic memories and other adverse life experience to the point of adaptive resolution.

What We Need & What You Get

Our Goal is Big because Our Dream is Big! 

  • These funds ($250,000) will be used to purchase property close to Willis, Texas, and to build the counseling center and a 16-man barracks that will house our intensive and long-term program clients.
  • Every contribution matters to the veterans and other clients we'll serve! Pictures of our progress, published "thank you's" in our newsletter, scrolling gratitude on our website, hoodies, advertising, memorial walkways, plaques and benches, even permanent dedication on the RTCC building are small tokens of appreciation for the profound impact your contributions will have on the lives of RTCC clients and their families.
  • Any and all funds received as contribution to Refuge Trauma & Counseling Center's Building Fund campaign will be poured into establishing a permanent residence for RTCC.

Your Impact

We Are Confident Your Contribution Helps Make the World a Better Place!

The impact your contribution has potentially changes the lives of thousands of people.  Family members, friends, acquaintances -- Every single person who has contact with just one person we help will be changed. As men change, families change, and communities change.

Remember - You are investing in the same ideals of patriotism, freedom and self-sacrifice that these men learned about growing up in America.

Risks & Challenges

They Risked It All - Are You Up for the Challenge?

Expanding our brand and securing funds for the foundation of a better future for these men we serve and their families are top priority for Refuge Trauma & Counseling Center. They are also our biggest hurdles. Please help us help those who risked it all.  Check-mark 'challenge accepted' and make your contribution today! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even Email Makes a Positive Impression!

Please be sure to share the message about Refuge Trauma & Counseling Center's Campaign with others in your network.

And please remember to use the IndieGoGo Share Tools!

story:
Advocate Cycles

Advocate Cycles is a bike company that exists solely to create innovative bicycles and deliver 100% of profits from the company back to making cycling better for everyone.

Advocate Cycles is using a new, pioneering legal approach called the Specific Benefit Corporation (SBC), a corporate form that started in Minnesota on January 2, 2015.  It is designed to help entrepreneurs start and grow social businesses and provide a guarantee to consumers that the social promise set forth is upheld.

Benefit corporations are like traditional for-profit corporations in most ways except that they make special commitments.  First and foremost, an SBC declares a legally binding social purpose, in addition to its general business purpose, which its directors and officers must consider when making strategic decisions for the business. As a means to be held accountable, SBCs must publicly report its progress toward the designated social purpose each year to the Minnesota Secretary of State. 

We have elected to pledge 100% of our after-tax profits to be donated to non-profits making cycling better for all people. Because of this pledge, we have no profit motive to offer investors, so we are asking for your support to make this first-in-the-industry company a reality.

We believe that benefit corporations are the next big movement in business in America. With growing support needs of non-profit organizations to have positive impacts, and growing skepticism of companies posting record profits, we feel consumers will start making conscious choices to support companies that support what they love. We believe that organizations such as the International Mountain Bike Association (IMBA), People for Bikes, and Adventure Cycling Association make cycling better, so we are starting out by supporting these organizations and intend to add many others as we grow.

Our president Tim Krueger has a long history with developing compelling cycling products. A benefit corporation cannot just rest on its mission; it is still a company that must compete with the rest of their industry.  So not only are we making a great promise about what we will do with our profits, but we are making excellent, modern, competitive product with an equal or better value proposition than the competition, leading out with our Hayduke™ and Watchman™ models.

What We Need

Advocate Cycles will be sold through brick & mortar bicycle shops across the USA and Canada.  We also think that to be great advocates of cyclists, we also need to support the local bike shops that make for a rich cycling culture in every city.  

We have self-funded the initial production run of Hayduke™ and Watchman™ models, and they are already in production and slated to arrive in late September.  To grow Advocate Cycles beyond just a few units, we need your help to fund our marketing and dealer efforts, develop future models, and grow Advocate into a full-line bicycle brand.  

Our primary goal this year is to be present at Interbike, the USA's #1 bicycle industry trade show, where most American dealers go to pick up new model lines. $10,000 will get us to Interbike so we can start signing dealers.  $30,000 will get us a more professional website. $50,000 would allow us to go into our 3rd model immediately!

If we exceed our funding goals, we will also start to add additional non-profit organizations as beneficiaries to our efforts.  

Our current business plan has us posting 7-9% of revenue as profits with a 2015 calendar year revenue goal of $330,000. With your help, we can hit our funding goals, sign up dealers, and easily surpass this plan. 

What You Get 

Naturally, part of this campaign is selling our Hayduke and Watchman framesets and complete bikes. We also understand that you may have a great bike already, so there are some other great perks to supporting us.  

      

Advocate Cycles Hats and Mugs

  • Adjustable, soft mesh-backed hats, complete with embroidered logo
  • Handmade Deneen Pottery mugs, made in St Paul, MN. Their "Abby" mug in Hunter Green with a blue/white glaze and our "Empower the Advocates" logo

Advocate Cycles Bolt Jersey by Club Ride

  • Custom printed with the Advocate Cycles logo with "i am a cycling advocate" on the sleeve
  • Available in sizes Small-XL
  • Main logo is color-matched to jersey fabric

Handmade Advocate Cycles Headbadge by Jen Green

  • Arguably the best headbadge jeweler in America, Jen Green of www.headbadges.com designed and made our "Empower the Advocates" logo from white brass.  
  • We know you probably love your existing bike. You can still show your support of Advocate Cycles by giving it a new headbadge!

Advocate Cycles Hayduke™ and Watchman™ framesets

  • Ready for delivery in September, our Reynolds 725 heat-treated chromoly framesets come complete with a Thomson Elite seatpost collar, choice of single or multi-speed dropouts, and a SRAM Maxle Ultimate.
  • MSRP is $750
  • Check out specifications and geometry at www.advocatecycles.com

Advocate Cycles Hayduke Titan™ and Watchman Titan™ framesets

  • Still in development, these double-butted 3/2.5 Titanium framesets use the exact same specifications and fitments as their chromoly counterparts
  • Advocate name on decal is available in a choice of colors to match or complement any anodized parts you may want
  • Expected delivery of December 2015
  • MSRP $1,950

Advocate Cycles Hayduke™ and Watchman™ Complete bikes

  • Advocate's Reynolds 725 chromoly frames build up into complete bikes!
  • Both bikes use SRAM's excellent and affordable GX1 11 speed group, RaceFace cockpit parts, Rockshox forks and tubeless wheels. For full specs, check out www.advocatecycles.com
  • MSRP of $2,650 for Hayduke™ Complete and $2,750 for Watchman™ Complete

Impact

Advocate Cycles can only start to grow with your support. We want to be the model of using profits for progress in the cycling industry.

  • Every year there will be increased need to turn cyclists into advocates. Whether it be lobbying for bike lanes or making cycling safe for children, our sport will need a strong support network to continue to survive. Every year there are millions of dollars of profits in cycling companies and we hope to harness a small portion of that to make cycling better. We also hope our growth will inspire other companies to follow our lead or step up their current support.
  • Tim has managed development of numerous popular and award-winning cycling products such as the Salsa Beargrease Carbon, Whisky No.9 Carbon rims, and Salsa Bucksaw. Working with this knowledge base and several established and trusted suppliers, the development and delivery of the product is already solidified and scheduled. 
  • Our team has a proven track record of innovative product and company growth. Once launched, Advocate Cycles has great potential to make a huge impact on the cycling industry's relationship between business and non-profit.

Risks & Challenges

We have 140 complete bikes and 60 frames arriving in late September. Even with that guarantee, there are still challenges.

  • The cycling industry is a very full market. While our unique business model and promise have earned us some early press, it will be very important to get the word out about who we are.  For our mission to succeed, we need to sell bikes.  And to sell bikes, we need to establish momentum. 
  • There is always risk of strikes, bad weather, and other delays when importing product. We have purchased appropriate insurance against these risks to protect against financial loss. 

Other Ways You Can Help

The greatest support we can get is recognition of our mission. If our mission sounds like something you can get behind, here are some ways to get involved:

  • Like our Facebook page and keep in touch with us as we make progress!
  • Wanna ride a bike before committing?  Tell your local dealer about us and tell us about them! 
  • Share this campaign using Indiegogo's sharing or your own social media!
  • Visit our website and sign up for our email list.

THANK YOU

  • A special Thank You to those that helped me get this project off the ground: Ryan Krueger Photography, Todd Hafermann Photography, Casey Krueger, Odia Wood-Krueger, Anna Schwinn, Porter Million, and Todd Larson.

Hayduke and Watchman Specifications

Hayduke


Watchman

story:
Now, we are running InDemand

We will offer this for a limited time, so if you missed out last time or would like more, this is the time. If you are interested in purchasing more than 10 devices or a partnership with WAY, please contact hello@helloway.co

한국어 소개 | 웹 구매가이드 | 모바일 구매가이드 

WAY in the press 

(Check us out on Refinery29 and Bustle)



Skincare Just Got Easier with WAY

WAY is a personal skincare companion, which collects real time data from your skin and the environment and provides practical skincare and beauty tips on your smartphone. The full solution comprises a simple, beautifully designed device and connected mobile app.


A small, beautifully designed device, WAY easily slips into your handbag and looks comfortable next to your beauty products.


#WAY Live Demo from The WAY Team


Why you need WAY?

Busy professional women and mothers lack time for themselves. Maintaining healthy, youthful skin takes time and dedication. With WAY, you can easily analyze your skin condition in just 3 seconds and receive tips about your skincare routine, that save you time and help you to look your best. 


How dose WAY work?

<Touch WAY>

WAY's built-in BIA skin sensor analyzes the moisture content & estimated oil balance of your inner skin. Using WAY you can check your skin condition on a connected device any time, anywhere.

Touch your skin with WAY at least once a day. Let WAY do the rest.

* BIA Skin Diagnosis: BIA skin sensors in the device detect the moisture content of your inner skin. This is the layer beneath the surface, which is a much more powerful indicator of the overall health of your skin than a surface reading.

By performing this deep level of diagnosis and providing tips for your skincare routine, WAY can help you better manage your daily skincare routine, and ultimately help improve the health and beauty of your skin.


<Always WAY>

WAY monitors UV and Humidity levels in the environment in real time, all the time.


- Protect your skin from harmful UV Radiation

WAY constantly tracks UV radiation levels and provides tips to help you stay safe, whether outside in the sun, or inside under UV lighting.

*Why you need UV Protection (From World Health Organization)
While some UV exposure is essential for production of vitamin D, over-exposure can lead to serious long term health concerns, including skin cancer. As well as excessive exposure to UV rays from the sun, artificial lighting indoors can contribute to skin damage. 
- Protect your skin from dry conditions

Most of know that dry conditions are not good for our skin, but it's tough to qualify dryness levels and take appropriate action. WAY was designed to help you track both the moisture content of your skin and environment. By constantly monitoring conditions and providing qualified skincare tips, WAY takes the mystery out of skincare.

*Why you need to monitor dry condition 
Dry conditions can contribute to premature skin aging. Therefore moisturizing is a vital step in keeping your skin healthy and beautiful. However,  most of us don’t know how dry our surrounding environment is, how it affects our skin, and what we should do about it.


<Follow WAY>

WAY provides personalized beauty tips and suggestions, using data from your skin and environment. 

Data collected from your skin and surroundings is aggregated with other real-time information (such as weather reports), to send practical skincare tips to your smartphone.  


Updated Product Information

Color Options: White & Silver / Black & Gold

- White & Silver

- Black & Gold


Device Specifications

- Size: 58mm x 58mm x 13.3mm (W x H x T)

- Weight: ~24g

- Rechargeable battery: USB charging with up to 5~7 days off of one charge.

- Material:  Anodized Aluminium, PC


Updated Schedule

- Actual 1st build (mass production) is scheduled on 11/30/2015

- Expected pre-order shipment from 12/15 (Starts with orders from US and Korea)


Qualified technology solution

WAY has teamed up with professional Dermatologists and Korea’s leading medical university for both development and validation of our technology. With this team of industry experts we are continuing to analyse initial clinical data to continuously improve the value of our service.

Dr. Ga-na Oh is an established dermatologist and joined our team as a Co-Founder in 2014. His industry expertise has helped us refine the technology solution and provide more accurate skincare tips. 

Note: While WAY provides qualified information about your skin and delivers tips for improving your skincare routine, it is not intended to replace medical instruction from a certified dermatologist.


Why WAY is special

A number of solutions exist that monitor skin condition, but none currently offer a full range of analysis (environment and skin condition). WAY goes far beyond analysis, and provides qualified and personalized beauty tips on your connected device. 

At WAY we are proud to have built the world's first 'total IoT skincare solution' which combines data from a number of sources and automatically provides beauty tips to our customers.

WAY abstracts the need to purchase costly dermatological equipment and far excedes the service levels of other similar solutions.


#WAY's Live Skin Testing Booth at SparkLabs Demo Day

Watch as the lady gets the rundown on her skin condition! SPOILER ALERT: She was clearly pleased ^_^ She joins the many satisfied with WAY, will you be next? Get WAY today!


The team at Way is passionate about creating services for women that maintain beauty and a healthy lifestyle. Founded in 2014 in Seoul's trendy Gangnam district, WAY is designed to meet the beauty and skincare demands of a modern woman's busy lifestyle.

Future Plans

At WayWearable we have been exploring the intersection of beauty, skincare and technology to bring you services that maintain your beautiful life, keeping you healthy and looking your best. WAY version 1.0 is just the first step.

Beyond providing practical beauty tips, we are working hard to further develop our recommendation service to include specific product recommendations, which target your unique beauty concerns.

Imagine if your WAY was able to assess your skin condition and environment and suggest specific products based on this data? You would be able to make better informed product choices, save money, and ultimately improve your beauty routine. We're not there yet, but with your help we'll be one big step closer.

We are building a better WAY for women to improve their lives and maintain their natural beauty. WAY is your personal skincare companion.

Follow your WAY, and join our mission to transform the beauty industry.


WayWearable’s CEO holds a major in economics from Yonsei University and prior to founding WAY Wearable operated as CEO of another healthcare startup, Design Your Body, for three years.

WayWearable’s CTO has a background in hardware and software development as well as  experience in IT consulting and Marketing in Hewlett-Packard.

In addition, WayWearable Co-founder Dr. Gana Oh, is a professional dermatologist at ‘Choice Dermatological Hospital’ in Gangnam and has helped the team build additional expertise in this area.

Other members of the team are engineers from Cornell University and experienced designers who have operated in the cosmetics industry and won a prestigious Red Dot Award.

Risks and challenges

Delivering hardware products on schedule is always tough. Thankfully WAY has been able to secure a prestigious manufacturing partner, Vision Scape in Korea. They extensive previous experience in working with wearable and IoT device companies, including Misfit Shine. We are confident that they have the expertise and capability to deliver on time and the proximity to our head office in Seoul will also be a major benefit. We are confident that together we will be able to rise to the challenges of meeting our projected shipment dates, with all pre-orders from Indiegogo delivered in November 2015.

We have now completed development of our Alpha Prototype, even before launching our campaign on Indiegogo, and this is a major boost. We are now progressing with obtaining KC, FCC and CE certifications, which will likely take 2 months.

We have also been running continual testing on our combined hardware and software solution with our Co-Founder Dr. Oh, who is a professional dermatologist. Results have confirmed that the service will provide reliable and accurate skincare advice. We will be running live testing at Korea's top technology and entrepreneurship event, beGLOBAL Seoul 2015, on May 14th ~ 15th in Seoul.

Why You Can Believe Us

Hardware development, production and distribution is tough, but we are well placed to deliver on our promise. Below are some of the concerns we’ve identified, with our action plan to secure success.

Manufacturing: We have already contracted an established manufacturing company in South Korea, which is capable of producing our product to the time frames we have set. The facility has extensive experience in manufacturing IoT products and has been thoroughly vetted by our internal team and external advisors.

Investment: We have already signed deals with local investors who have made financial commitments to WAY Wearable and are helping us connect with strategic partners and future clients.

Strategic Partners:  We are currently in discussions with a number of world renowned cosmetics manufacturers in Korea. They are providing strategic support and will offer powerful global marketing assistance once we begin full production. Once final details of partnerships are confirmed, we will update.

Business Acceleration: Our company and product development is being accelerated by SparkLabs, one of Asia's most respected business incubators. We are proud to have been accepted into their current batch and with the help of their staff, mentors, and investors we are moving rapidly towards our goals.


Why we need your support

We have already raised finances to cover product development and testing, but to bring WAY to market we an additional USD $50,000 to manufacture the first 1,000 units and kick off our marketing activities. Once we have achieved this we will have validated our business concept with investors, with whom we have forged relationships over the last year. Achieving this mile-stone will also help us secure distributors. At this stage we would be able to ramp up to full production capacity.


FAQ

Q: Does WAY come with an App?

A: Yes, we have already developed a companion app for our WAY device, which will be available for both Android and iOS by the time of our first shipments. The app will help you manage the device and will display your skincare tips. The app comes free with all WAY devices.


Q: Does it keep a record of the data collected? If yes, can the user see this record?

A: Yes, a record of collected data is stored. This will be used to build a personal user profile that will add depth to the personal tips provided by WAY. Customers will have access to any data collected from their device.


Q: If more than one bluetooth device is paired with the user phone, will it impact the data collection or analysis?

A: No, you can pair more than one bluetooth device, including WAY, with your smartphone.


Q: What are examples of the tips given?

A: Our tips include ‘alerts’, ‘personalized beauty suggestions’ and 'Skincare product recommendation'.

  1. Alerts: "It's too dry. Time to use facial mist." / "The UV index is [XX]. WAY recommends factor [XX] sunscreen."

  2. Personalized beauty suggestions: “You need to drink more water.” “These days, your skin is drier than normal. WAY recommends using additional moisturizer.”

  3. Skincare product recommendation: “I have been with you for 1 week and I found that your skin has exposed to very dry environment. People who have similar environmental and skin condition use these following skincare product…”


Q: If a particular brand of product is recommended, I think it is best to recommend one with an international presence so that international backers can benefit

A: We will launch a skincare product recommendations after all Indiegogo pre-orders have been delivered. These recommendations will be taken from a large brand pool, to ensure all customers can benefit.


Q: Any reason why WAY chose flexible funding?

A: We chose flexible funding because we were confident of delivery, even if we didn’t meet the indiegogo funding goal. As it happens we already have, with over five weeks remaining.


Q: Is WAY water resistant?

A: Some sensors in WAY require ventilation. Therefore, WAY is not water resistant.


Q: Is this product developed for women only or is there a version for men?

A: The current design of WAY is targeted towards women, but the solution is equally applicable for men and women.


Q: How do I charge my “WAY”?

A: WAY comes with usb charging, and a cable to connect with any USB charging port (eg in a laptop or PC). You can use WAY up to 5-7 days with one time charge.

Q: What materials are used for the device?

A: WAY is primarily comprised of aluminum and plastic.


Q: Will the completed version of WAY have same design to the one in the pictures and video?

A: The finished design is likely to be almost identical to the one pictured. There may be the need to add small ventilation holes on WAY, to allow proper access to the atmosphere, for the sensors. This will have minimal impact on overall design.


Q: How does the device differentiate between fingers holding it and the face it’s supposed to read?

A: The device has a specific skin sensors, which are located on the bottom of the device and appear as two dots. You should put this specific sensor part on your facial skin and push the ‘Analyze’ button in the mobile application to get the analysis results. The device will analyze your finger if you push ‘Analyze’ button with your finger on the specific sensor part.


Q: Is the device recommended use on one person alone, or can one device be used (for example) by a couple?

A: Yes, you can share WAY with others. However, data collected by WAY only saves on one account. This is so because a user profile accumulates data to personalize your skin care experience with WAY. Hence, although possible to use for more than one person, it is ideally used solely by you.


Legal Disclaimer - "Delivery of rewards/perks are subject to best efforts and not guaranteed."

Now, we are running InDemand

We will offer this for a limited time, so if you missed out last time or would like more, this is the time. If you are interested in purchasing more than 10 devices or a partnership with WAY, please contact hello@helloway.co

story:
Thank you for visiting my site! I have been a professional golfer for about 4 years now and have made it to the final stage of LPGA Qualifying (Final Stage) 3 times. I have had a win on the LPGA Symetra Tour in 2014 (similar to webdotcom tour on men's side) and feel that I am closer than ever to making it.

Being a professional golfer is a difficult life though as the expenses are remarkably high. I am raising money to pay for my expenses on the LPGA Symetra Tour and also for 2016 LPGA Qualifying School. Symetra Tour entry fees ($500/each), travel expenses for all events, coaching fees, training/course fees and Q school (at a $6,000 entry) have combined for an expensive past few years. 

I often play in Pro-Am's all over the country with four individuals from particular cities. These people are often CEO's, business owners, employees, etc. I travel each week to a different town or city for my events and I can help represent you, your business or find ways to help you learn the game or teach clinics to you/your friends. If you are interested in developing a sponsorship relationship in which we can find ways to grow together through golf/golf-outings, please let me know.

Thank you for visiting, any amount can help and I appreciate your interest in supporting me and women's golf as I try to reach the top level of the game.

Warming up before an event

2014 LPGA Final Stage Q School

Photo taken at Lakenheath Air Force Base in England


Junior clinic and event in Curacao with my friend Joanna Coe

story:
Our Story

Hi, my name is Sal. Ranny, a dear friend since high school needs help right now. He is 44 years old, a husband and a father of four small children, Raphael 13 yrs old, Angelica is 10, Jerick is 6 and Jennica who just turned 4.   

A couple of months ago, Ranny was dignosed with esophageal cancer in its advance stage. After undergoing a couple of chemo treatments, his health turned for the worse. Not only did the tumors grow and spread, but doctors recently diagnosed him with sepsis which is presence of bacteria in his blood. This has left him a very weakened state in which he is unable to work or support his family. That is why we need your support. If you are able, we are asking for any help you can give.

 

The Impact

We need your help to raise money for Ranny's treatment and his family's basic needs.  His supportive wife, Jenny, has been his rock through this process.  But Jenny has to work during the week, so she cannot provide Ranny with 24/7 care he needs, and they do not have the resources to pay for a nurse. The money Jenny earns isn't enough to cover all of the medical expenses, not to mention their rent, childcare, and other basic necessities.  We would love to raise enough money to cover all of these costs, as well as allow Jenny to take more time off of work when she needs to take care of Ranny.

 

What We Need

All the money we raise will be used to pay for Ranny's medical bills and the family's expenses.  Our goal is to raise at least $10,000 for Ranny and his family.  As Ranny battles cancer, we want monetary costs to be the last thing on his mind.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us spread the word about this campaign, we need all the support we can get!  Share this page with everyone you know, and 'like' our facebook page:http://www.facebook.com/GoRannyFundraiser Thank you for your generosity!

story:
Janet Rowe was diagnosed with MS in 2005. Until 2011 her symptoms progressed slowly, however in the last year her health has taken an unfortunate turn. Her balance, coordination, mobility, fatigue, and heat intolerance are considerably worse.

On Friday June 9, 2012 a fundraiser was held by an arts collective in Toronto called Almost Not Quite, to help raise money for Janet's procedure. They were able to raise almost $1000 towards the goal!

 

In the last four years it was discovered that many people who suffer from MS also have CCSVI, a narrowing of major veins, which affects blood flow to the brain. There is a simple, procedure to correct CCSVI, but it is not yet available in Canada. We have to pay a large sum out of pocket for Janet to receive this treatment. The surgery costs approximately $6500 and has pretty astounding success rates. The closest most affordable clinic is in Albany, NY and Janet would be able to have the treatment as soon as July.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise approximately $5500 to be able to pay for the surgery in Albany.

The Impact

We are very hopeful that the CSSVI treatment will alleviate Janet's symptoms particularly as the heat of the summer inches closer. Those who suffer from MS often have a harder time in extreme weather conditions. We anticiapte the procedure will make walking easier, improve her balance and coordination and lessen her fatigue and sensitivity to heat. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it.
story_txt:
Janet Rowe was diagnosed with MS in 2005. Until 2011 her symptoms progressed slowly, however in the last year her health has taken an unfortunate turn. Her balance, coordination, mobility, fatigue, and heat intolerance are considerably worse.
On Friday June 9, 2012 a fundraiser was held by an arts collective in Toronto called Almost Not Quite, to help raise money for Janet's procedure. They were able to raise almost $1000 towards the goal!
 
In the last four years it was discovered that many people who suffer from MS also have CCSVI, a narrowing of major veins, which affects blood flow to the brain. There is a simple, procedure to correct CCSVI, but it is not yet available in Canada. We have to pay a large sum out of pocket for Janet to receive this treatment. The surgery costs approximately $6500 and has pretty astounding success rates. The closest most affordable clinic is in Albany, NY and Janet would be able to have the treatment as soon as July.
 


What We Need & What You Get
We need to raise approximately $5500 to be able to pay for the surgery in Albany.


The Impact
We are very hopeful that the CSSVI treatment will alleviate Janet's symptoms particularly as the heat of the summer inches closer. Those who suffer from MS often have a harder time in extreme weather conditions. We anticiapte the procedure will make walking easier, improve her balance and coordination and lessen her fatigue and sensitivity to heat. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!


And that’s all there is to it.

story:
The Inspiration: A Mermaid's Call for Your Help

Since I've had the privilege of traveling to Thailand on two occasions, I have a visceral appreciation for the people and the land.  Much of my time there was spent IN the water so my association of Thailand with water is very strong. 

On my second trip, I got live out a childhood fantasy:  to swim in the ocean as a mermaid!  The incredible beauty of the Andaman sea really touched my heart and soul...

Little Woo Mermaid video in Thailand: http://vimeo.com/23359832

This winter, when I learned that many people in Thailand are not able to get clean drinking water after the recent flooding (its worst flooding in decades), my heart yearned to offer some help at their time of need...

Read about the flooding: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Thailand_floods


The Intention

In Vancouver, we drink some of the cleanest water on the planet straight out of our kitchen taps! 

With gratitude for what we have, let's provide clean drinking water for Thai people who have suffered from the devastation of the floods!


Any amount you can donate will help:
Whether you can send $5, $50 or $500, any amount will make a difference!  Many contributors make light work...

New Recipient:  Engineers Without Borders (EWB)
My friend Tzvi has done a lot of research and advised me that Engineers Without Borders does incredible relief work regarding clean water projects.  I contacted EWB International last week and they confirmed that they have a Thailand project so I will send the funds there instead of the Lifesaver Filters since it will go farther with EWB. 


Your Intervention

Please SHARE this campaign with your friends and family in the Lower Mainland...

It's best to include a personal note about how you have already donated or how you know me (little woo) so that they know this is a real and very local effort...

Let's see how quickly and how much clean water Vancouver's grassroots community can offer to the people of Thailand!!!

Much love to you all for your compassion...

xox little woo mermaid..

story:
Why?            

We need to improve our practice grounds!  We just do not have enough space, and the little space we do have is unlevel, full of rocks or a basketball court.

Our school is located on top of a mountain and all the sports at the High School and Elementary School share this one field and a basketball court for practice.  My friends and I would love to play sports after school but there is so little space.  And, we are too far from better facilities :(. 

Please help support this project so that after a long day of classes we too can play!

The Community

La Trinidad National High School is located in Lubas, La Trinidad, Benguet Philippines.  It’s a small community with about 2,000 residents.  People are mainly farmers and it’s a big struggle for them to send their kids to school.  Thus, students go to school with a very minimal allowance or worst none at all.  The community is a bit far from the main town and most people walk as means of transportation.  Children would normally do the same going to school.  The school’s budget does not provide much money to purchase sports equipment.

Besides financial problems for many of the students they face family issues at home that can range from parents not being home (whether working or overseas), raising younger siblings, deceased parents, drunk parents.  To go along with this many students are addicted to computer games.  They will not only cut school to play, they will lie to their parents, steal, skip meals, not sleep in order to play at the computer shops.  However, sports and in particular school sports can help steer the students in the right direction.

The elementary school situated directly above the high school faces many similar issues.

The Problem

One of the major issues for the students at La Trinidad National High School (LTNHS) in Lubas La Trinidad, Benguet, Philippines is absenteeism.  From July 4, 2011 to August 12, 2011 36% of first year, 20% of second year, and 24% for third and fourth year students were absent from school.  Among the more than 400 students, 295 committed 464 absenteeism incidents.  Absenteeism is a leading cause in the schools failure rate and dropout rate.  The teachers have found that they can use sports to motivate students to come to school, since many love playing sports, therefore not only decreasing absenteeism incidents, but also, decreasing the dropout rate.

However, the students have trouble practicing because there is limited space at or near La Trinidad National High School.  The school is situated on the mountainside making level land space even more limited.  All the land that is currently available near the school is the elementary school’s basketball court and small field (which is not flat, covered in rocks, and is smaller than a basketball court).  Thus, when students want to practice they must either share the limited spaces or travel to better playing facilities.  Travelling not only takes time but, it costs the students money that they do not have. 

The Project

We are trying to expand and improve the space we have for practicing/playing sports.  By improving the field as we are planning to do, it will give us significantly better and more space to play. 

We hope that this will increase the student participation  in some of our sports and other extracurricular activities and in doing so will hopefully motivate our students to excel to greater heights inside and outside of the classroom!

What you can do to help

Every donation small or large can help this project.  We appreciate any and all support in whatever way you can provide it.  Please:

  • Donate what you can
  • Share this with your friends and family
    • Facebook
    • Email
    • Etc

Maraming Salamat Po (Much Thanks)!!!
