story:
Race Information & Fact Sheet

Race Across America (RAAM) is one the most respected and longest running endurance sports events in the world. RAAM is seen as a pinnacle of athletic achievement not only in cycling circles but the greater sporting community as well.

RAAM has a rich and storied history. In 1982 four individuals raced from the Santa Monica Pier in Los Angeles to the Empire State Building in New York City. Covered by national television, the race captivated the public’s imagination. Teams were added in 1992 and quickly became the most popular and fastest growing segment of the race. Relay team racing made the event accessible to any reasonably fit cyclist. The 2014 race will be the 33rd edition of RAAM.

There is no other race in the world like RAAM. The Race inspires everyone who has been a part of it - racer, crew, staff and fans alike. RAAM is the true test of speed, endurance, strength and camaraderie, the ideal combination of work and fun! There is no race that matches the distance, terrain and weather, no other event that tests a team’s spirit from beginning to end.

2014 Race Information:

·Start: Oceanside, California – Oceanside Pier   Relay Teams – Saturday June 14·Finish: Annapolis, Maryland – City Dock June 20-24

·Route: 3000 miles, 170,000 feet of climbing

·Crosses 12 states, passes through 88 counties and 350 communities

·Format: Solo, 2-, 4- and 8-Person relay teams

This Ain’t No Tour

RAAM is a race! But unlike the three great European Grand Tours (Tour de France, Vuelta a España and Giro de Italia), RAAM is not a stage race. RAAM is one continual stage, similar to a time trial. Once the clock starts it does not stop until the finish line. RAAM is about 30% longer than the Tour de France. Moreover, racers must complete the distance in roughly half the time allowed for the Tour.

More importantly, RAAM is not limited to professional cyclists. RAAM is open to professional and amateur athletes alike. While solo racers must qualify to compete, anyone may organize a team and race.

Racers must traverse 3000 miles across 12 states and climb over 170,000 vertical feet. Team racers have a maximum of nine days and most finish in about seven and a half days. Teams will ride 350-500 miles a day, racing non-stop. Solo racers have a maximum of 12 days to complete the race, with the fastest finishing in just over eight days. Solo racers will ride 250-350 miles a day, balancing speed and the need for sleep.

Team or Solo?

There are different divisions in which to race. There are 2-, 4- and 8-Person relay teams. The workload may be split up any way the teammates choose. On an 8-Person team, each racer will ride roughly three hours per day. Solo is just that - one person travels the entire distance. Whether team or solo you will have a support crew following you. The support crew handles all of the logistics – food, fluids, navigation, clothing changes, medical needs, bike repairs, etc. - so that racers can focus on racing.

Who Races RAAM?

Racers come from all over the world and all walks of life. Racers are both amateurs and professionals. But, the majority of racers are ordinary people with a passion for riding their bicycle. Racers range in age from 13 to 75. Every year there are racers from at least 15 countries. Over 25 countries have been represented over the 30-year history of the race. Approximately 40 % of the racers are from outside the US. About 15% of the racers are women.

Why Race RAAM?

Some might echo George Mallory’s sentiment about Mt. Everest, “Because it’s there!”

For most racers it is not that simple. Reasons include raising money for a charitable cause, setting a record, seeing the country, spending time with friends, adding their name to the finishers list, etc. But, overwhelmingly most people race RAAM simply to have fun and challenge themselves.

Whatever the reason, RAAM is an incredible journey across a beautiful country! Not a single racer will walk away unmoved by the achievement.

Racing for Charitable Causes

RAAM is an outstanding platform for raising money for charitable causes. Racers annually raise collectively in excess of $2 million for a wide range of charitable causes.

Media Exposure

Fans from all over the world follow RAAM. Fans can follow RAAM on the web, through the bi-weekly RAAM Newsletter, race blogs, the social media (Facebook and Twitter) and traditional mainstream media. There is local, national and international coverage by the traditional media. Additionally, RAAM has at least four of its own media crews on the course providing up-to-date video, photo and text coverage. Race coverage statistics:

·  25+ million page views annually

·  2500+ articles in mainstream media(TV, radio and print)

This coverage provides substantial value to both sponsors and charities.

The Executive Team

RAAM is run by a dedicated group of professionals, who also happen to race bicycles. Our executive team is comprised of Fred Boethling, President (2X RAAM finisher) and Rick Boethling, Executive Director (RAW founder). Together we bring a very strong business and race background and understanding ofwhat makes a great event.

2012 Race Statistics

·340 racers and 1000+ support crew (includes RAW)

·27 Different Countries (includes RAW)

·  60 Teams, 58 Solos (includes RAW)

·  250+ staff & volunteers

RAAM is an Epic Event

Race Across America is the world’s top endurance cycling event. The 2014 race is the 33rd  edition of RAAM. We expect the largest field and the most extensive coverage in the event’s history. Don’t miss out!

story:
Short Summary

  • My name is Frank, My uncle Roger has worked all his life.  He started driving Buses and then Tractor trailers when he first received his license. He also constructed many homes as a volunteer for Habitat for Humanity.
  • This campaign was started to help Uncle Roger during his cancer recovery and other situations that follow his surgery that left my uncle homeless and now jobless with a disable nephew also homeless.  It hurts Roger to ask for help from anyone, he has work most of his life., Now he finds his self and nephew needing help
  • Help receive from contributors will help us find a low income home and my uncle can continue his care of himself and of my traumatic brain Injury.  He can also recover from a very painful surgery and he can return to work.

 

As a thanks to anyone who helps with comments, suggestions, share ideas or that would just like a small token of my appreciation, I will send a comic book from my collection.   The comic book is a small way of saying Thank You from the bottom of my hearth.   I have a huge collection that a friend agreed to store for me temporarily.  I no longer have a home to keep something that has giving me so much joy reading during the years and It will make me happy to share them with other to enjoy.  My comic book collection has been part of my life for many years and was the only thing that I did not lose because a college friend stored them in his basement.   My name is Frankie.   My uncle name Rog is my best friend and only family member.   Rog and I have shared an apartment for 17 years.

 

Rog has truly helped so many people during the years.  I have never heard him say no to anyone needing help.  He is very receptive and has always been there for anyone needing him in our community.  He has been working since he was 16 and for the last 18 years he has work driving trucks over the road, as a truck and bus instructor and as a safety officer training workers at the ports.  In his spear time and as a hobby, Rog fixes homes for those needing him in our community. He learned construction skills by volunteering for habitat for humanity.

 

I suffered a traumatic brain injury while I was completing my medical school degree.  The injuries left me totally disable.  Rog has been there for me and has support me in many ways.  He makes sure people understand my injury and many times he has prevented kids in the neighborhood from making fun of me.  He educated people in stores and places we go.  He tells them my speech impediment was because of a traumatic brain injury and to please have a little patience.  He reminds me of all my medical appointments.  He takes me to my appointments and when he is not able to, he makes arrangement so that I could get to my appointment safely.     He fixed our apartment to prevent and minimize me from obtaining any further injury.  He fixed our cabinet to automatically close so that I won’t leave them open and bang my head on them.   He placed guards in dangerous pointy areas on the furniture.   He placed padding in the small patio in the apartment so that I won’t suffer an injury.  He saw me through many seizures, cluster headaches and narcolepsy. 

 

I had a dark room that he set up for me to get over the migraines that last days.   Roger found ways that made it easy for me to learn and remember things again and he shared many methods with my doctor’s traumatic brain Injury group.    Rog did all this while juggling between work and making sure that I was safe and he did it all with patience and a smile.  On his own time he helps other young people interested in learning to drive trucks and buses. 

 

Rog also help many people who could not afford truck driving school and he never asked nor expected anything in return.  Rog words to me where, it is so satisfying when I see these students driving with a good paying profession and they say, thanks Rog.  He always stressed to the younger kids that staying in school and haven a profession is the best thing they can do.  Rog always believe that no matter how bad things get that live move forward and things get better.  The only dream that I have heard Rog tell me is that he wishes that one day we could have our own home, and that he will continue to work every day that he can to make that dream one day come true.

 

Rog was diagnosed with cancer in the buttock region going upward to the coccyx bone in the lower spine.  The cancerous tissue was all removed leaving an injury that was not healing quickly.  A very huge amount of tissue was removed from one side of the buttock and some from the other and a small amount near the lower spine. .

 

Rog lost his job during his recovery, and in the meantime 5 months had passed and I was doing my best taken care of the rent and the bills. Rog knew it was impossible for me to pay everything by myself and against doctors’ orders he started searching for a job.  During the medical exam that truck drivers are required to have; he continuously failed them because the surgical injury was still raw and open.  No matter how hard I tried, I was approximately 3 months at this point behind on the rental responsibilities. 

 

The landlord took us to court.   Although, the judge knew that I was permanently disable and she saw all the paper work for Rog cancer surgery, there was nothing she could do.  The judge was sympathetic and told Rog that if the landlord could not make an arrangement with us then she had no other options but to issue an evict order.  After living in this same place for 10 years, and never once being late before, the landlord did not reach an agreement that we could meet and an eviction order was issue. 

 

We were giving 24 hours to vacate the premises and 7 days to remove our things from the apartment.  We both had no money at all because we had giving the landlord 1 month and owe them an additional 2 months.  The landlord had proceeded with the eviction order. We slept 8 days in an old car that Rog had at the complex’s parking lot. 

 

All our things were thrown in the garbage because we had no money for storage or a truck to move the things from the apartment.  The complex towed the car out of their property.  That same day I manage to receive my disability check direct deposit.  

 

I used my monthly disability check to get a room at Extended Stay America.  The room has a two eye stove and a refrigerator. I paid for a10 day at 81.00 a day and I bought a little food that way we can cook and don’t have to buy takeout food.  Rog has been looking for a job and at this point he is willing to accept any job available so that we could get out of this terrible situation.  Rog has attended various interviews in the bus/ truck business but due to the physical requirements that are required by a physician, Rog continuously fail the physical.    

 

The worse of what we are going through is that I know it only a matter of days, before we have to go back to the streets.   I am so scared because the car we slept in is no longer available and the temperatures have dropped.  I never taught that we would end up in such a helpless, hurtful, and terrible situation.  We lost the only place that we could call home, and everything that we had worked so hard to obtain over so many years.  I see the hurt in my uncle Rog eyes and he sees it in mines.    Rog tries to make me feel better by saying that the things we have lost were only material things. 

A lifetime of pictures, books that I loved so much, furniture that were extremely hard to obtain, and so many things, are all gone.  It is so hard that I just don’t want to even think of it because it hurts too much.  The most important thing to me at this time is haven a place to sleep, cook and not be in the street. I am so scared for me and my uncle.  We only have a few days left at this place and no way to extend or stay.

 

The situation is almost hopeless.  I am trying to find a place that I could afford by myself for me and my uncle.   It pains me because Rog is doing everything he can to find a job again.  He tells me that he will work until he dies and he is attempting to find any available employment.     I am haven a very difficult time finding a rental because the landlord placed an eviction judgment in our records.  Bus service is so limited in the area that we are staying and we are haven difficulties moving around. 

 

What make this situation even more injurious and devastating is that we were told to call the department of social services and explain our situation in detail.  Rog called the state help number first before we lost our apartment and he explained the situation.   They made an appointment to come in and see a worker at emergency services.  Rog waited for 3 hours and the worker made him fill out a ton of forms. Rog felt embarrassed and humiliated because he has worked all his life. Rog was told he did not qualify for help to prevent eviction because the emergency service funds were only for people who received welfare.

 

We were evicted and lost everything and are currently staying in a hotel like studio.  I called social service and we explain the situation.  I asked them is there any way we can be assisted in finding a roof over our heads.  I explain that we were currently staying in a furnished room with stove refrigerator and if they could assist me with a partial voucher because my disability monthly income was only enough to cover 10 days at the cheapest location I was able to find.  I explain it was for a short time providing us time to find an affordable place to rent and given Rog time to find a job.  Rog is willing to start working immediately regardless of his medical condition.

 

Social Service exact words, we understand that your uncle Rog is your care taker and you have a permanent disability but we have no provision for the disable in this state.  Your uncle has been taken care of you for the last 10 years and what we do in a case like this is send you to a shelter and send him to another shelter.

 

Furthermore we have no control of the shelter that your uncle goes to and which one you go to.  Social Service went on to say, be aware that the shelters make you get up in the morning and you are not allow back in until 5:00pm.   Something is extremely wrong with what two different governmental agencies have said to me and Uncle Rog. 

 

Uncle Rog has taken care of me and I depend on his care.  He reminds me where I am at during a seizure.  He feeds me when I am force to be incapacitated in bed 2 and 3 times a week with debilitating cluster headaches. Uncle Rog calls my doctor and that make sure I am in dark quiet room.  Rog cooks and watch over me so that I don’t accidentally hurt myself.   Uncle Rog knows when I am haven a narcolepsy episode.  He had made our apartment safe to prevent further injury or accidents when he was at work.  He had our apartment equipped with cameras that he access from his phone.   He monitors my medications and make sure I take them as instructed by my specialist.  Uncle has been taken care of me for the last 13 years.  He has dedicated himself to make sure I was well taken care off and at the same time allow him to have his career.   It has taken years to form this Symbian relationship. The type of environment that social service is suggesting would be devastating to my health.  Rog does not even want to think about such an arrangement.  My specialist of 13 years is extremely concern about my care.  I quote my doctor when he says that I will decompensate and all the hard work and progress would be lost. He does not understand how could something so outrageous even be suggested or consider with a traumatic brain injured individual that has been declare permanently disable.   

 

Rog goals were to have the cancer surgery and allow his wound to heal.  He then was going to get a second job to save everything he made for a year because he wanted to buy a cheap fixer upper house and use his skills to fix it, one room at a time. Now that we are homeless I find myself thinking of anything that would have given us a roof over our heads.  

 

I also think of Rog desperation shortly after surgery of wanting to return to work.  It has been 6 months after Rog had the surgery and wound care has not clear him because the wound area continues to rip.  Rog has not followed doctor’s orders.  He has been looking for a job and riding the bus all over sitting for hours.  Rog after taken the bus walks for miles to locations with no bus trying to find a job.   My uncle has slept uncomfortable in a car and it made it hard caring for the wound.   Uncle has not been eating properly, and has done very little bed rest as order by his cancer Surgeon. The pic is the removal of cancerous tissue from the buttocks to the lower spine.  I asked God to please save my uncle and let all the mutated cells be gone.  

 

I want him to get better and for his wound to heal.  Our time here at Extended Stay is limited and I am asking for any type of help.  Your help will really be appreciated and will never be forgotten.  I thank you from the bottom of my hearth.  Any help would truly be appreciated by me and uncle Rog. And you will receive per your request a comic book from my collection

 

 

Thank you friends

 

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

  • The funds I need is $20.000 this will be used to prevent us from returning back to the streets, to allow my uncle to fully recover, to find an affordable home, for transportation expenses to medical appointments and to help and bring attention towards the lack of resources available to help families in preventing homelessness and the loss of everything due to cancer.
  • In return for your thankful contribution you will receive a classic comic book from my old collection all comic books are in excellent to good conditions. The more you contribute the more classic comic you will receive.
  • Obtaining our goal will pay for as long as needed to continue to stay at Extended Stay America while my uncle Rog recover and it will also keep us warm and out of the streets.  It will also help us locate an apartment that I can afford and that the landlord would rent to us. 

The Impact

 

  • In my search to find help for people experiencing the loss of their livelihood due to becoming ill because of Cancer, I found no agency or organizations that provide assistance.
  • I was surprise that in our country an illness can drive hard working individuals to become homeless overnight.  I was shock to learn that only people receiving welfare can qualify for a small stipend to prevent homelessness.  Those like us who are not in a governmental program and who have worked all our life are denied any type of funds.  
  • Your contribution will make a big difference in helping my Uncle Roger recover from cancer and provide us a temporary place to stay.  It will also allow us to find an affordable apartment.  It will prevent a separation of my care taker from me for no fault of our own.   It will provide peace of mind that my uncle may continue his treatment and recovery without the stressed and the desperation of finding employment, even though, the surgeon has not clear him to return to work.

 

My goal is to temporarily fund where me and Rog are staying which is Extended Stay America.  I have been looking desperately for a Rental that I can pay on my own without Rog.  I want to give him time to Heal and to find employment.  Rog’s goal is to find employment immediately because of our current situation.  Although Rog is still in the recovery process, he feels he has no choice but to find a job.  Haven been in med school for two year and I was just months from starting my third before my Traumatic Brain Injury, I notice that Rog surgical injury is not healing properly.  I am concern about a few areas that appear like abscesses that are indicative of a reoccurrence of cancerous cells.  I am trying to help so that he could feel comfortable enough, that our homeless situation is resolved.  I want Rog to go back to the surgical Oncologist for further treatment without the immediate worries of haven surgery or treatment without a home.  I have personally experience that there is no help for our situation.  There are many agencies but they do not provide direct help to those that need help when they have cancer and become homeless because of cancer and other disorders. It is my hope that if I can raise enough funds to get out of our immediate situation that I can use any extra funds raise to directly help others that become homeless because of cancer treatment.  It is so important to prevent homelessness before it occurs because after the fact it is so difficult to have a disease and to be homeless simultaneously.  The goal should be homelessness prevention to help those who have cancer and become homeless find a place to live.   Agencies exist to help with the free treatment of cancer but none help those that become homeless because of the disease.  Helping this specific group who work hard all there live and because of cancer become homeless or that are at risk of becoming homeless due to cancer is truly a worthy cause that I cannot ignore.    What do you receive for your help?

You will receive comic book from my classic collection.   

Other Ways You Can Help

 

  • It is imperative that we bring attention to cancer, treatment, employment and homelessness.  We often give donations to big corporations that do not offer help to those that have to make a choice between their job and receiving lifesaving treatment.
  • It is my hope that more people can speak up about this issue that so many experienced without having a place to turn for help.  Research is very important. Aggressive treatment and hope is important. I have learned that there are many heroes that provide excellent research and even free treatment for those with cancer. 
  • I have also learned and realized that like us this disease can destroy a family unit and leave them homeless with no way to turn.  We really need organizations that can make it their mission to help people seek treatment without sacrificing everything they have and becoming homeless in the process.
  • I am ready to make it my mission to overcome this situation with contributors help and to offer help to others that are in the same situation that we are experiencing. We must speak up loud and clear to everyone who can listen.  We should make everyone aware of the existence and need to a situation that anyone can experience. 
  • We should encouraged the treatment of cancer and assure the patients that they will not lose their home, family and employment during their treatment.
story_txt:
Short Summary

My name is Frank, My uncle Roger has worked all his life.  He started driving Buses and then Tractor trailers when he first received his license. He also constructed many homes as a volunteer for Habitat for Humanity.
This campaign was started to help Uncle Roger during his cancer recovery and other situations that follow his surgery that left my uncle homeless and now jobless with a disable nephew also homeless.  It hurts Roger to ask for help from anyone, he has work most of his life., Now he finds his self and nephew needing help
Help receive from contributors will help us find a low income home and my uncle can continue his care of himself and of my traumatic brain Injury.  He can also recover from a very painful surgery and he can return to work.
 
As a thanks to anyone who helps with comments, suggestions, share ideas or that would just like a small token of my appreciation, I will send a comic book from my collection.   The comic book is a small way of saying Thank You from the bottom of my hearth.   I have a huge collection that a friend agreed to store for me temporarily.  I no longer have a home to keep something that has giving me so much joy reading during the years and It will make me happy to share them with other to enjoy.  My comic book collection has been part of my life for many years and was the only thing that I did not lose because a college friend stored them in his basement.   My name is Frankie.   My uncle name Rog is my best friend and only family member.   Rog and I have shared an apartment for 17 years.
 
Rog has truly helped so many people during the years.  I have never heard him say no to anyone needing help.  He is very receptive and has always been there for anyone needing him in our community.  He has been working since he was 16 and for the last 18 years he has work driving trucks over the road, as a truck and bus instructor and as a safety officer training workers at the ports.  In his spear time and as a hobby, Rog fixes homes for those needing him in our community. He learned construction skills by volunteering for habitat for humanity.
 
I suffered a traumatic brain injury while I was completing my medical school degree.  The injuries left me totally disable.  Rog has been there for me and has support me in many ways.  He makes sure people understand my injury and many times he has prevented kids in the neighborhood from making fun of me.  He educated people in stores and places we go.  He tells them my speech impediment was because of a traumatic brain injury and to please have a little patience.  He reminds me of all my medical appointments.  He takes me to my appointments and when he is not able to, he makes arrangement so that I could get to my appointment safely.     He fixed our apartment to prevent and minimize me from obtaining any further injury.  He fixed our cabinet to automatically close so that I won’t leave them open and bang my head on them.   He placed guards in dangerous pointy areas on the furniture.   He placed padding in the small patio in the apartment so that I won’t suffer an injury.  He saw me through many seizures, cluster headaches and narcolepsy. 
 
I had a dark room that he set up for me to get over the migraines that last days.   Roger found ways that made it easy for me to learn and remember things again and he shared many methods with my doctor’s traumatic brain Injury group.    Rog did all this while juggling between work and making sure that I was safe and he did it all with patience and a smile.  On his own time he helps other young people interested in learning to drive trucks and buses. 
 
Rog also help many people who could not afford truck driving school and he never asked nor expected anything in return.  Rog words to me where, it is so satisfying when I see these students driving with a good paying profession and they say, thanks Rog.  He always stressed to the younger kids that staying in school and haven a profession is the best thing they can do.  Rog always believe that no matter how bad things get that live move forward and things get better.  The only dream that I have heard Rog tell me is that he wishes that one day we could have our own home, and that he will continue to work every day that he can to make that dream one day come true.
 
Rog was diagnosed with cancer in the buttock region going upward to the coccyx bone in the lower spine.  The cancerous tissue was all removed leaving an injury that was not healing quickly.  A very huge amount of tissue was removed from one side of the buttock and some from the other and a small amount near the lower spine. .
 
Rog lost his job during his recovery, and in the meantime 5 months had passed and I was doing my best taken care of the rent and the bills. Rog knew it was impossible for me to pay everything by myself and against doctors’ orders he started searching for a job.  During the medical exam that truck drivers are required to have; he continuously failed them because the surgical injury was still raw and open.  No matter how hard I tried, I was approximately 3 months at this point behind on the rental responsibilities. 
 
The landlord took us to court.   Although, the judge knew that I was permanently disable and she saw all the paper work for Rog cancer surgery, there was nothing she could do.  The judge was sympathetic and told Rog that if the landlord could not make an arrangement with us then she had no other options but to issue an evict order.  After living in this same place for 10 years, and never once being late before, the landlord did not reach an agreement that we could meet and an eviction order was issue. 
 
We were giving 24 hours to vacate the premises and 7 days to remove our things from the apartment.  We both had no money at all because we had giving the landlord 1 month and owe them an additional 2 months.  The landlord had proceeded with the eviction order. We slept 8 days in an old car that Rog had at the complex’s parking lot. 
 
All our things were thrown in the garbage because we had no money for storage or a truck to move the things from the apartment.  The complex towed the car out of their property.  That same day I manage to receive my disability check direct deposit.  
 
I used my monthly disability check to get a room at Extended Stay America.  The room has a two eye stove and a refrigerator. I paid for a10 day at 81.00 a day and I bought a little food that way we can cook and don’t have to buy takeout food.  Rog has been looking for a job and at this point he is willing to accept any job available so that we could get out of this terrible situation.  Rog has attended various interviews in the bus/ truck business but due to the physical requirements that are required by a physician, Rog continuously fail the physical.    
 
The worse of what we are going through is that I know it only a matter of days, before we have to go back to the streets.   I am so scared because the car we slept in is no longer available and the temperatures have dropped.  I never taught that we would end up in such a helpless, hurtful, and terrible situation.  We lost the only place that we could call home, and everything that we had worked so hard to obtain over so many years.  I see the hurt in my uncle Rog eyes and he sees it in mines.    Rog tries to make me feel better by saying that the things we have lost were only material things. 
A lifetime of pictures, books that I loved so much, furniture that were extremely hard to obtain, and so many things, are all gone.  It is so hard that I just don’t want to even think of it because it hurts too much.  The most important thing to me at this time is haven a place to sleep, cook and not be in the street. I am so scared for me and my uncle.  We only have a few days left at this place and no way to extend or stay.
 
The situation is almost hopeless.  I am trying to find a place that I could afford by myself for me and my uncle.   It pains me because Rog is doing everything he can to find a job again.  He tells me that he will work until he dies and he is attempting to find any available employment.     I am haven a very difficult time finding a rental because the landlord placed an eviction judgment in our records.  Bus service is so limited in the area that we are staying and we are haven difficulties moving around. 
 
What make this situation even more injurious and devastating is that we were told to call the department of social services and explain our situation in detail.  Rog called the state help number first before we lost our apartment and he explained the situation.   They made an appointment to come in and see a worker at emergency services.  Rog waited for 3 hours and the worker made him fill out a ton of forms. Rog felt embarrassed and humiliated because he has worked all his life. Rog was told he did not qualify for help to prevent eviction because the emergency service funds were only for people who received welfare.

I want him to get better and for his wound to heal.  Our time here at Extended Stay is limited and I am asking for any type of help.  Your help will really be appreciated and will never be forgotten.  I thank you from the bottom of my hearth.  Any help would truly be appreciated by me and uncle Rog. And you will receive per your request a comic book from my collection
 
 
Thank you friends

story:
Rochester, N.Y. – Family members are mourning the loss of two brothers who drowned Tuesday afternoon in Irondequoit Bay.

Mon Tay has eight children, but lost two of them in the tragic accident. Keo Nhong, 29, and Chanta Nhong, 27, both of Rochester, died after going under during a boating trip.

“He was a good man, a good daddy, a good husband, the youngest son, said Tay of Chanta Nhong. “He was my baby,”

The brothers, who were inexperienced boaters, set out for a day of tubing with Chanta Nhong’s 9-year-old son and his friends.

“Apparently, the tube struck a wave and Keo Nhong and nine-year-old, Paul (Castro) were ejected from the inner tube into the water while the younger child was still in the tube,” said Monroe County Sheriff Patrick O’Flynn.

Paul Castro swam back to the tube, and helped bring Chanta Nhong, Jr. to the boat. He then called police.

Chanta Nhong jumped off the boat into the bay to save his brother.

“He would die for his brother, his own flesh and blood,” said Navy Nhong, the eldest sister of the Nhong family.

Neither brother wore a life jacket.

It took roughly 50 people six hours to locate the bodies of the Nhong brothers.

 

We are asking just for a little bit of help from the public to help raise money for their funeral and also to help Genny Chanta's wife out with anything else she may need in this time of need. Chanta and his brother were close friends to my family and I want to do anything I can to help. Thank you in advance for your donations. Anything helps. A video of this horrible incident can be viewed at whec.com or wham 13 or R-news for verification. Thank you and God Bless

story:
Hello to all fellow Indiegogoers! 

Our little Ari has VERY BAD TEETH!! She used to like sleep with her bottle at bedtime, and as a result, her four front teeth are COMPLETELY DESTROYED!

We feel like terrible parents! Ari has trouble chewing her food as her biters are of no use!!

She has to eat chicken wings and the other foods that are supposed to be enjoyable with the side of her mouth. Poor baby! 

We carried her to the Dentist and the dentist suggested giving her a dose of VALIUM and pulling all four! Plus she suggested we put replacement teeth so the other teeth don't move in the space and to help with her speech instead of just leaving a spacer.

The thing is, we would never put my daughter through that TORTURE!

VALIUM!? HELL NO! Not from all the HORROR STORIES I read online about kids NOT WAKING BACK UP AND DYING!

So we were looking at other options and came across this site;

http://www.drbialik.com/before-a-after-photos


The Dr. Scott does AMAZING work! I can't believe how GREAT those kids teeth look after! 

Take a look at the link above for yourself! All done with NO DANGEROUS SEDATION or NEEDLES or PULLING! Just a Special Composite Filling! 

We had no idea this was even Possible!

The problem is we live in The Bahamas, very far away and the cost to travel all the way to this Amazing Dr.(Connecticut) and have the Necessary work on our precious, little Ari's teeth will cost us a small FORTUNE. 


My wife and I are both working, but we also have two other children, Plus mortgage payments, light bills, school fees, food etc. you know the basic things we all need in life. 


I came across this site and said, "What the heck!?" Let's give it try! I see one old lady ask for a vacation and got over $700k! Wow must have been some kind of Vacation! Lol :)


So people, What the Heck!? Donate $1 or Donate $100. It's for a real good cause, and those who are Parents, I hope you never have to see your child's teeth go through what Poor Lil Ari is going through now.


Thanks guys and gals! The Power in many united, can help change the world to a better place. :D *Smiles*


Help Save and Share A Smile Today! :))

Let's give it try! I see one old lady ask for a vacation and got over $700k! Wow must have been some kind of Vacation! Lol :)So people, What the Heck!? Donate $1 or Donate $100. It's for a real good cause, and those who are Parents, I hope you never have to see your child's teeth go through what Poor Lil Ari is going through now.Thanks guys and gals! The Power in many united, can help change the world to a better place. :D *Smiles*Help Save and Share A Smile Today! :))

story:
Leaf & Love Organic Lemonade was created when we (Amy and Sara- friends since childhood) took to our kitchens to develop a tasty, organic, zero-grams-of-sugar lemonade. We were sick and tired of children’s beverages filled with sugar, artificial sweeteners, and crazy ingredients we couldn’t pronounce! Yet, at nearly every birthday party, playdate or sporting event, our kids were drinking typical juice boxes while we cringed at the thought of all that sugar.  The latest research is showing that even 100% juice is nearly as detrimental as sugar-filled drinks, as far as how our bodies respond to it.

We couldn’t be more excited to bring a better beverage to families everywhere. Leaf & Love Organic Lemonade offers the perfect balance of sweet and sensible in every box!


Left: Sara and Allie Lou at Oakland Children’s Hospital at diagnosis
Leaf & Love was largely inspired after Sara’s daughter, Allie Lou, was diagnosed with Type 1 diabetes at age three. Type 1 diabetes is an auto-immune disease which is not caused by eating too much sugar, but it does require the child keep a tight balance of carbohydrate/sugar intake and insulin injections. Happily, now Allie Lou can enjoy a refreshing, zero-sugar, 2 carb lemonade anywhere she pleases!

Right: Julian and Amy, Mother’s Day 2014
Leaf & Love was also inspired by Amy’s perpetual search for wholesome and delicious nutrition that wouldn’t have her four-year-old son Julian bouncing off the walls all day long! Now, Amy doesn’t think twice about offering Julian and his buddies this yummy treat, and the other parents couldn’t be happier.



Are you ready for the scary truth? A study conducted by the American Heart Association found that children as young as 3 years old already bypass the daily recommendation of 3-4 teaspoons (10-12 grams) of added sugar per day. This age group typically consumes around 12 teaspoons of sugar a day. That translates to 48 grams of added sugar every day or a minimum of 38 pounds of added sugar every year!  We bet you would be shocked to find that even some of even the “healthiest” food and beverages marketed to kids sneak sugar into their ingredient panels.

Leaf & Love Organic Lemonade is a category creator! We are the first all-natural, organic and zero-grams-of-sugar juice box for families.

We went through several rounds of formulation and taste-testing to ensure that our beverage would be highly appealing to kids.

Leaf & Love is:

  • USDA Certified Organic
  • 5 calories/2 carbs per box
  • Non-Gmo
  • Vegan
  • Low Glycemic Index
  • Gluten-Free
  • Sweetened using only the highest quality organic stevia leaf extract


Learn a little more about Leaf & Love:




At Leaf & Love, giving back is important to us both personally and professionally. If we reach our funding goal, we will give a portion of our crowd-funding to Insulin for Life-USA www.ifl-usa.org. IFL is a unique non-profit that is dedicated to sending medical supplies to children in developing countries who would not survive without them. Furthermore, Leaf & Love donates a portion of all sales to this incredible organization.


Leaf & Love is conducting a "fixed" funding campaign, which means it is "all-or-nothing." If we don't reach our goal, no funds will be collected from anyone. So, you can see what a serious impact every contribution will have on our future!

How we will use the funds:

Sara and Amy completed their first run of Leaf & Love Organic Lemonade in July​ ​of ​2014​​.​ ​Their lemonade ​was ​​such a​n immediate​ hit​, ​they ​already ​need to make more! ​

In order to do this they need​ to​:

  • Rent out a manufacturing facility
  • Print and produce the aseptic juice box containers
  • Source high-quality, USDA ​o​rganic ​i​ngredients
  • Pay for the warehousing of product and transportation logistics
  • ​Become Kosher Certified as this is important to us and ​many customers​

With your help, Leaf & Love will be able to complete our next run if we meet our goal!  However, if we surpass our goal, we will use any additional funds to build the business and help grow our vision of Leaf & Love as the "go-to" brand for healthier beverage options. We will foster research and development of more flavors and different package sizes to meet various family needs.

​​Amy and Sara are very dedicated to giving back and would like to continue donating ​product to schools and also to charities that serve the Type 1 diabetes community​.​


OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP: Make some noise about our campaign!
Whether or not you are able to contribute to Leaf & Love, you can definitely help us out by spreading the word about our campaign. Use the "share" buttons above to share our endeavor with your friends, or we would be grateful if you post about us on your social media pages!

story:
***WE ARE NO LONGER ACCEPTING DONATIONS FOR THIS CAMPAIGN. THANK YOU TO ALL WHO SUPPORTED THIS PROJECT.***


You Might Be Suffering From A Cannabinoid Deficiency

All animals (including you) have an Endocannabinoid System. This recently discovered physiologic system plays an essential role in regulating overall health and wellness in the body. When the system breaks down, the result can be injury, disease and death. 

Clinical Endocannabinoid Deficiency (CECD) has been implicated in the development of a growing list of aging-associated diseases such as Type-2 Diabetes, Alzheimer's Disease, Inflammatory Diseases, Heart Disease and Cancer. 

What if we could eliminate this deficiency by replacing our body's lost "endo" cannabinoids with plant based, "phyto" cannabinoids? Could we slow the aging process and add a significant number of healthy years to the average human lifespan? We need your help to find out.

Using Cannabinoids To Extend Lifespan in Mice

Team CPMC will be competing for the Palo Alto Longevity Prize. The Palo Alto Longevity Prize is a $1 million life science competition dedicated to ending aging. Team CPMC was assembled to compete for the Longevity Prize by attempting to raise the world's oldest and healthiest laboratory mouse! 

Drs. Sean McAllister Ph.D & Pierre Desprez Ph.D are scientists at the California Pacific Medical Center Research Institute and are the lead researchers for Team CPMC.

We designed this experiement to determine whether two compounds found in the cannabis plant, Cannabidiol (CDB) and Delta-9 Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) can be effective in treating Clinical Endocannabinoid Deficiency and extend healthy life in mice.

                         

              

Cannabidiol (CBD) is a non-toxic, phytocannabinoid that is increasingly being used in food and medicine. THC, another well known phytocannabinoid, may be taken orally in food or as medicine and has also been proposed to enhance the therapeutic effects of CBD.

Due to CBD's wide range of pharmacological effects as well as its antioxidant properties, our hypothesis is that CBD administrated orally, as sesame oil pellets, in combination (or not) with THC, in young, middle-aged or old mice will significantly increase their lifespan. Let's see if we can break the record for the world's oldest-ever living mouse!

Does this mean that our mice will get "high" from the THC? The answer is NO. CBD is known to counteract the psychoactive effects of THC. Because our mice will always receive much more CBD than THC, we don't expect them to experience any psychoactive effects what-so-ever. Our mice will be happy, but not that happy!

The total cost for this project is estimated to be $177,000, including a $2000 registration fee for the competition. The experiment will be conducted using 105 mice assigned to 7 different experimental groups. 15 mice per group. Including three groups treated with CBD, three groups treated with CBD and THC. And one control group.

Groups 1 & 2 will determine the potential effects of CBD and CBD in combination with THC, on lifespan in 16 month old female C57BL/6 mice.

Groups 3 & 4 will use 9 month old mice that will receive the cannabinoid therapy for 6 months before being allowed to reproduce.

Group 5 & 6 will include the offspring of the mice from groups 3 & 4. This group will receive the cannabinoid therapy from utero to end-of-life.

Group 7 is the control group.

The mice will be kept in plastic cages containing sawdust bedding (4 mice per cage) in an animal holding room that will be maintained at 21–24°C and 40–60% relative humidity with a 12 hour light/dark cycle. The mice will be provided food (Purina Certified Laboratory Chow), plenty of water and all the exercise they need.


We Have 2 Chances To Win!

The Palo Alto Longevity Prize is actually 2 prizes. A  $500,000 Homeostatic Capacity Prize will be awarded to the first team to demonstrate that it can restore the health of an aging mammal to that of a young adult.

A $500,000 Longevity Demonstration Prize will be awarded to the first team that can extend the lifespan of its animal by 50% of the accepted published norms. To qualify to win this prize at least 10% of our mice will need to survive beyond 1,425 days. 

We believe that by attempting to break the record for the oldest-ever living mouse, we will be in an excellent position to win both prizes. The current record holder was a genetically engineered mouse that lived for 1,819 days. To break that record, at least one of our mice will have to exceed that record by one day for a total of 1,820 days.

Timeline

The Palo Alto Longevity Prize ends on September 9th, 2018. So we have to get the ball rolling quickly if we are to meet the requirements to win the prize. Our experiment will begin on July 1st, 2015 with the first 4 groups of mice, plus the control group. Groups 5 & 6 should be born sometime in January or February, 2016.

If all goes well, on September 9th, 2018, the mice from groups 1 & 2 will be 1,678 days old. Groups 3 & 4 will be 1,439 days old. If 10% of any of these groups is still alive on this date then Team CPMC will qualify to win the Longevity Demonstration Prize.

Groups 5 & 6 will reach world record age of 1,819 days + 1 day, some time in February, 2021.

The maximum length of project is approximately 5 Years, 8 Months.

Real Science, Real Life Implications.

The use of cannabinoids in food and medicine has increased significantly over the past decade and promises only to become more widespread as doctors recommend medical cannabis for an ever-increasing number of ailments. But the long term effects of phytocannabinoids in our diet needs to be better understood.

We expect this project to yield a wealth of useful data on the relationship between cannabinoids and the diseases associated with aging. But the project also promises to be great fun! The Palo Alto Longevity Prize is a competition designed to produce a quantum leap in regenerative medicine. So in the spirit of that competition (and human progress) Team CPMC is on a mission to produce the world's oldest-ever mouse and win that prize! But we need your help to do it!

Please support this project and make a contribution today!

Thank you!

story:
There have been many horrific stories on the news recently, and the one that particularly caught my attention was the earthquake in Nepal. Nepal is so beautiful, and the most recent earthquake has caused devastation throughout the country. Over half a million people have lost their homes, and almost all hospitals in affected districts have been destroyed; the hospitals that are still standing are overflowing with patients. With the approaching monsoon season, the population of Nepal are at huge risk of disease and infection.

In December 2015 I will be trekking as part of 'Projects Abroad' to Nepal to be a Medical Volunteer. I will be observing and assisting with healthcare in Nepal; providing help in orphanages, emergency care centres, AIDS centres, local hospitals and schools. In addition, I will be assisting with the rehabilitation of baby elephants that have been affected by the earthquake.

In order to do this vital work I need to raise £2000; this will cover the cost of my Visa, immunisations, accommodation, insurance, and travel within and to/from Nepal for 2 weeks. Volunteer projects like mine are imperative if the people of Nepal are to recover from this horrific natural disaster. 

Thanks, 

Maisie :)

story:
A Summary

My name is Jennifer and I am the founder of a non-profit, World Health Equity (WHE). I'll be running the NYC Shape Women's Half Marathon on April 17th and am asking for support for one of World Health Equity's projects in the process. WHE needs help equipping a clinic for 25,000 villagers in Sierra Leone, West Africa. Today, these villagers have to travel hours across dirt, pot-hole ridden roads to reach the nearest district hospital. They frequently die of malaria, cholera, snake bites, mishandled childbirth, simple infections and car accidents – each cause preventable with appropriate medical care.  
My goal is to  raise just over $150 for each of the 13 miles I will run for a total of $2,000 toward equipping this clinic. I kindly ask for your help in empowering some of the world's most vulnerable (who make less than $2 / day) to lift themselves out of health inequity and into the promise of a healthier, brighter future. 

A few details about our project:

World Health Equity: Who We Are

World Health Equity (WHE) is an accredited 501c3 federal tax exempt non-profit organization. 

What We Do
WHE aims to ensure that the basic right to healthcare for those individuals in the impoverished communities we serve is met. WHE strives to make health services more affordable and more accessible by helping strengthen health systems through partnerships with Ministries of Health, community health associations, medical schools and other organizations. WHE has two ongoing projects: Baby Box and Bamoi Clinic (additional information on both projects available on our website), The focus of this fundraiser will be to support the establishment of Bamoi Clinic in rural Sierra Leone.

About Bamoi Clinic
Over the past year, WHE has supported the provision of healthcare for a rural community of farmers in northern Sierra Leone. The Bamoi Community of farmers, with a population of 25,000, is prone to the world's 3rd highest maternal mortality and 11th highest infant mortality rates. Thanks to our sponsors, WHE is now working with the Bamoi Community and Bamoi Health Association to establish a permanent clinic that will be integrated in Sierra Leone's national health system through a partnership with Sierra Leone's Ministry of Health.

What We Aim To Accomplish And What We Need 

Our Goal

WHE wishes to support the establishment of a sustainable clinic for the villagers of Bamoi. Achieving that goal requires 3 phases:

We have $10,000 raised so far to completely fund Phase I, which is the construction of Bamoi Clinic. As construction efforts begin, WHE is fundraising to support Phase II - equipping the health center with beds, a generator, a fridge, supplies required to run a basic clinic, and a vehicle for emergency transfers to the district hospital.

Our Ask

For your help toward funding Phase II of Bamoi Clinic's construction - equipment costs that will total $15,000. 

This, our first campaign, is seeking $2,000 to fund the four bedroom in-patient center with basic furniture, which include beds, chairs and consultation table.

The Impact

Your contribution will support the men, women, children and elderly of Bamoi in overcoming their current lack of access to a basic right we take for granted in the developed world. In the longer term, your contribution will be a small but important step toward improving the state of health inequity of Sierra Leone.

Risks & Challenges

Our work is not without risks. Fundraising for a project that benefits individuals who do not offer significant return on investment for the majority of donors is challenging and slow, and our extended project timelines reflect that. Additionally, we source labor mainly from the Bamoi Community in order to encourage continued ownership of the clinic's development by the Bamoi villagers themselves. Consequently, we tend to experience project delays as experts not available within the Bamoi Community have to be identified and brought into the project team, however we do our best to anticipate and respond proactively to such needs.

Despite these hurdles, we are confident in our team's capacity to successfully establish Bamoi Clinic with the support of our partners on the ground. Our team is led by Sierra Leoneans and Bamoi Community members (including the Bamoi Chief),  who are best equipped to handle the day-to-day challenges we encounter. Additionally, our leadership and board of directors have relevant experience in fundraising for and executing education and healthcare projects in Africa. They have been integral in outmaneuvering fundraising challenges we have experienced thus far. 

Finally, World Health Equity has an established track record of successful projects with the Bamoi Community and broader Sierra Leone. WHE supported a pilot clinic for Bamoi, which in one year saw 10% of the community's population (2,500 villagers). WHE has won the support and partnership of the Sierra Leone Ministry of Health on this project. Additionally, WHE supports the Sierra Leone Ministry of Health address postpartum hemorrhage (a lead cause of maternal death). WHE initiated a partnership with Harvard Medical School and led the execution of a maternal health program in Sierra Leone, which has since been implemented nationally. Today, 50 mothers and their babies have been saved due to this program. It is with this past experience and familiarity with Sierra Leone that I confidently request your support for my team in addressing health inequity at Bamoi. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some of you may not be able to contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help! Any contribution--monetary, service or advice--is tremendously appreciated so please forward our campaign to your co-workers, friends and family members to spread the word.

On behalf of the residents of Bamoi and the team at World Health Equity,

Thank you!!

WHE wishes to support the establishment of a sustainable clinic for the villagers of Bamoi. Achieving that goal requires 3 phases:


We have $10,000 raised so far to completely fund Phase I, which is the construction of Bamoi Clinic. As construction efforts begin, WHE is fundraising to support Phase II - equipping the health center with beds, a generator, a fridge, supplies required to run a basic clinic, and a vehicle for emergency transfers to the district hospital.
Our Ask
For your help toward funding Phase II of Bamoi Clinic's construction - equipment costs that will total $15,000. 
This, our first campaign, is seeking $2,000 to fund the four bedroom in-patient center with basic furniture, which include beds, chairs and consultation table.   The Impact Your contribution will support the men, women, children and elderly of Bamoi in overcoming their current lack of access to a basic right we take for granted in the developed world. In the longer term, your contribution will be a small but important step toward improving the state of health inequity of Sierra Leone.
Risks & Challenges
 Our work is not without risks. Fundraising for a project that benefits individuals who do not offer significant return on investment for the majority of donors is challenging and slow, and our extended project timelines reflect that. Additionally, we source labor mainly from the Bamoi Community in order to encourage continued ownership of the clinic's development by the Bamoi villagers themselves. Consequently, we tend to experience project delays as experts not available within the Bamoi Community have to be identified and brought into the project team, however we do our best to anticipate and respond proactively to such needs.
Despite these hurdles, we are confident in our team's capacity to successfully establish Bamoi Clinic with the support of our partners on the ground. Our team is led by Sierra Leoneans and Bamoi Community members (including the Bamoi Chief),  who are best equipped to handle the day-to-day challenges we encounter. Additionally, our leadership and board of directors have relevant experience in fundraising for and executing education and healthcare projects in Africa. They have been integral in outmaneuvering fundraising challenges we have experienced thus far. 
Finally, World Health Equity has an established track record of successful projects with the Bamoi Community and broader Sierra Leone. WHE supported a pilot clinic for Bamoi, which in one year saw 10% of the community's population (2,500 villagers). WHE has won the support and partnership of the Sierra Leone Ministry of Health on this project. Additionally, WHE supports the Sierra Leone Ministry of Health address postpartum hemorrhage (a lead cause of maternal death). WHE initiated a partnership with Harvard Medical School and led the execution of a maternal health program in Sierra Leone, which has since been implemented nationally. Today, 50 mothers and their babies have been saved due to this program. It is with this past experience and familiarity with Sierra Leone that I confidently request your support for my team in addressing health inequity at Bamoi. 
Other Ways You Can Help
 Some of you may not be able to contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help! Any contribution--monetary, service or advice--is tremendously appreciated so please forward our campaign to your co-workers, friends and family members to spread the word.
On behalf of the residents of Bamoi and the team at World Health Equity,
Thank you!!

story:
ReForm combines features to optimise maximum performance

The ReForm top targets shoulders, delts, and back, subtly correcting posture to aid both pulling and pushing movements.

ReForm grips key areas on your body unlike current compression clothing, to offer support through full range of movement.​

Shoulder and elbow stabilization, allowing you to push yourself further.​

WHAT'S SO DIFFERENT?

Our Patent Pending garments were dreamt up to remove the need for Kinesiology Tape as much as possible. Utilising specially developed materials, constructed in a unique pattern design, the materials offer a further level of pinpointed support and heat where you need it most, in conjunction with our soft-stick panelling to replicate how Kinesiology tape interacts with the skin, without the need to have a trained individual applying the tape, or the uncomfortable peeling off of the tape. The garment slides on and off without irritation, whilst providing Kinesiology tape and Compression garment like benefits, all in one from fitting streamline garment we call ReForm.

 

Muscle injuries are a huge part of our lives

We've combined the best features of both Compression wear ad Kinesiology Tape

You may be wondering

K- TAPE is a rehabilitative taping technique that is designed to facilitate the body’s natural healing process while providing support and stability to muscles and joints without restricting the body’s range of motion as well as providing extended soft tissue manipulation to prolong the benefits of manual therapy administered within the clinical setting.

It really is a brilliant piece of kit, however timely to apply, requiring a trained individual to apply it correctly, and very costly when used a lot. It’s often not viable for many, ReForm brings you the same principles in an easy to apply garment offering the benefits of both Kinesiology tape, and compression wear in one streamlined garment. 

ReForm’s dual layered Lycra backed material grips the skin where you need it most to offer support never felt before in a compression garment

 

WHY ARE WE ON INDIEGOGO?

We’ve seen how supportive you the Indiegogo community are, and now is when we need your help. We believe we have created something truly unique. All we want to do at Python Performance is create amazing products you never thought were possible to make, and our ReForm Range is just the first in a series of innovations to come out. 

We need your help to raise enough funds to hit our minimum order quantities, and run the first batch of ReForm garments. We can’t do this without you, so please hit the green back this project button and join us on our journey.

 

 

PLEASE HELP US SPEAD THE WORD, SHARE OUR CAMPAIGN WITH FRIENDS AND FAMILY

 

Sizing is very important with ReForm - So please take a close look before ordering

Sizing is very important with ReForm - So please take a close look before ordering

EXCHANGE POLICY

We understand buying online can sometimes mean the fit isn’t exactly as you imagined and you may like a smaller or larger garment. 

The sizing guide should give you accurate sizing to ensure your ReForm garment is working at its optimum level for you. However, should you wish to exchange your garment for any reason, we would be more than happy to exchange it for a different size. All we ask is that you send back your ReForm garment with all the related labels it came with. 

In future, our products will always be sent out with a return postage stamp should you wish to exchange or return. As of yet, we are just starting out, and offering you our ReForm Range at a heavily discounted price. We will regretfully not be able to accept any returns, and you will have to pay for the cost of shipping the garment back to one of our collection points in your country of residence. We will however ensure to share the cost by shipping your replacement garment on us as soon as we receive the item to be exchanged.

SHIPPING

We do all of our shipping through DHL, so rest assured our logistics once your product has left us are in capable hands. All our standard shipping is included in the amount you back us for. 

We’ll be emailing all of our backers as soon as the products land with us to offer an express delivery service to speed up shipping. This will be an opt-in service at a later date which will cost $9.99 for worldwide express deliver and £6.99 for UK express delivery.

story:
Hello friends and family,

I am raising money to run the NYC Marathon in November for Fred's Team, Memorial Sloan Kettering's fundraising program for cancer research. 
The money the program raises goes directly to Memorial Sloan Kettering, which not only improves cancer research and care at MSK, but also helps spark progress at centers worldwide that look to our institution to set the standard of achievement and pace of innovation.
I'll be running with the Send It Foundation in honor of Send It founder, Jamie Schou. In the Spring of 2012, Jamie was diagnosed with a rare form of cancer called a Synovial Sarcoma. Since then, he endured 20 chemotherapy treatments, 33 doses of radiation, and over 20 hours of surgery. He started his non profit organization in order to  bring outdoor experiences and adventures to cancer fighters and survivors. 
I was blessed to have met Jamie through a friend of mine. He was a lover of life and the outdoors, forever enthusiastic and always grinning. Jamie lost his battle to cancer earlier this month. We will be running in honor of him in November. 
I need to raise the full $3500 in order to receive a bib for the race. If I cannot achieve the goal, the money will be returned to you. Please help me run in honor of Jamie!
"Cancer can take my hair, take parts of my body, take my time but it will never take my smile!!"- Jamie Schou

story:
About Kinetic Diagnostics (KDx)

We are passionate about maximizing performance and minimizing injuries for athletes at all levels. No matter if you are a professional athlete or weekend warrior, we want to connect you with proven training regimens, cutting edge genomics, lab testing and sports medicine experts using your smartphone, tablet or personal computer. All the tools and incentives to exceed your goals for performance, with safety in mind, will be right at your fingertips. 


Our team is comprised of leading experts in genomics, laboratory testing, and sports medicine. We have partnered with the best and brightest in mobile engagement to bring you the best experience possible. 

We are looking to raise $50,000 through Indiegogo to build out our exercise library and provide athletes and sports professionals with the ability to pre-order services to help support our launch in Summer 2015. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are raising $50,000 to help support the launch of our application in Summer 2015. This project will be used to develop the full exercise library content needed for our customized training regimens and to provide those that share our passion to pre-order services.

Contributors, should they choose, can receive the following perks based on contribution level:

  • Public thank you on social media and your name on our contributors page (all)
  • Athlete app download when we launch in Summer 2015 (all)
  • Stainless steel KDx water bottle
  • KDx Long Sleeve T-shirt
  • Sports genomic profile, 90 genes
  • Sports genomic profile, exome (>22,000 genes)
  • Baseline blood profile
  • Performance blood profile
Some perks include video consultations with KDx network experts.

Why This is Important

We all know that getting injured is something that can happen when you play sports. In fact, 1 in 5 ER visits in the US are related to sports, resulting in >$33 billion spent on direct medical costs for those injuries. While a good percentage of those injuries aren't preventable (like a resistance band breaking unexpectedly or getting tackled), many injuries can be prevented with proper training regimens. Let's take the example of anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) tears. Over 200,000 happen in organized US sports each year, and the average surgical repair is $27,000! Using proper warm up and training techniques, however, such as the FIFA 11 regimen in soccer, can prevent 30-50% of ACL injuries with the added bonus of a significant improvement in agility, maximal oxygen use, and overall performance. 

A lot of people don't know about that, though, and we want to change that. Don't you want to know that you, and the athletes and fitness enthusiasts you love, are doing everything possible to perform well while minimizing the risk of preventable injury?

The KDx solution will allow athletes to identify the right training regimens to maximize performance and minimize injury for their sport. It can be further tailored and customized using genomic profiling, blood test monitoring, and by connecting with leading experts in sports medicine, physical therapy, training, coaching, nutrition, sports psychology and genetics. 

If you want the list of references that supports all this data, email us at tbrown@kineticdx.com

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help spread the word by sharing our campaign with your friends, family and co-workers. Even if you can't donate right now, it will be a big help to share our project with others. We are going to be giving away some prizes for "shares," "likes," and "tweets" so please send to your friends!

Our Team

Trish Brown, Co-Founder and CEO. Ms. Brown is a genetic counselor who has been at the forefront of business and genomics for over 2 decades, working for medical centers and companies such as Duke University, LabCorp, DNA Direct, Medco Health Solutions, and Omicia.

Jim Valentine, Co-Founder and Chairman. Mr. Valentine  is the President and Chairman of Valentine & Company. His particular expertise involves the organization, governance and financing of emerging growth companies involved in technology infrastructure and services. He has served in a variety of key management positions as well as a financier and investor.  Mr. Valentine was a General Partner of Montgomery Securities, serving as Managing Director of the Corporate Finance Technology Group. Mr. Valentine serves on the boards of directors of a variety of technology companies both public and private. 

Paul Billings, MD, Ph.D.- Chief Science Officer & Director Dr. Billings  is currently the CMO of Omicia, Inc. Prior to Omicia, he was CMO at Life Technologies, acquired by Thermo Fisher Scientific, Inc. Before that he was founding and acting Director and CSO of the Genomic Medicine Institute at El Camino Hospital. Dr. Billings served as President, CEO and Director of CELLective Dx Corporation. He is a Founder of CBR Systems Inc., and GeneSage Inc. Dr. Billings was also SVP and Senior Geneticist at LabCorp. He is currently a Director at Trovagene and CollabRx. Dr. Billings currently serves on the Scientific Advisory Board of the FDA, the Genomic Medicine Advisory Committee at the Dept. of Veterans Affairs, and the National Academy of Sciences Institute of Medicine’s Roundtable on Genomics.

Mike Aicher, Director Mr. Aicher is the CEO of Omicia, Inc and the founder and former CEO of National Genomics Institute,  now a wholly owned subsidiary of LabCorp. Mr. Aicher led LabCorp’s Western Division and was previously responsible for the company’s Esoteric Business Units, which generated more than $1 billion in annual revenue. Prior to NGI, Mr. Aicher served in a number of executive leadership roles at Central Diagnostics Laboratory. He is certified by the University of California at Berkeley as a Global Biotechnology Executive and is a recipient of Ernst & Young’s “Entrepreneur of the Year” award for emerging technologies. 

Nick Caulfield, CTO. Mr. Caulfield is a technology executive with nearly two decades of experience focusing in the healthcare and retail industries. Mr. Caulfield is co-founder and CTO of RocketReel. Prior to joining Kinetic Diagnostics, Nick was the Senior Director of Technology at DNA Direct, a Medco Healthcare Solutions Company (now part of CareCore National). Mr. Caulfield has also held executive and leadership positions at a leading retailer and managed strategic direction for transactional and analytical systems. 

Nicole Teed, Product Development. Ms. Teed is a board-certified genetic counselor and the owner and principal consultant at Integrity Genomics, LLC. She is an experienced leader in the genomics industry. In her previous role at Sequenom Laboratories, she helped launch the MaterniT21 PLUS non-invasive prenatal test for chromosome abnormalities and supported expansion of testing throughout the US and into the international market. Previously, Ms. Teed supported clinical product development and genetic counseling services at DNA Direct, a San Francisco-based start-up that was acquired by Medco Health Solutions. 

Dan Anderson, Training Development 

Mr. Anderson is a certified personal trainer through the National Academy of Sports Medicine (NASM). He holds certifications for Performance Enhancement Specialist and Corrective Exercise Specialist. He also has extensive training in re-integrated neuromuscular positional therapy, degenerative disc and spine training techniques, and kinesio taping. He studied sports medicine and worked with the athletic department at Diablo Valley College, providing experience in clinical injury evaluation and rehabilitation for college athletes. Mr. Anderson has over 5 years experience in a large corporate gym setting, and has recently transitioned to full time Founder and Owner of Quality of Life Fitness Coaching. He implements evidence training programs methodically put together from referencing the best science and brightest minds. Each week Mr. Anderson trains multiple individual clients, small groups, and manages corporate wellness programs.
